Microsoft's design previously featured a smiley with hands and feet.

A yellow face with raised eyebrows, enlarged eyes, slight frown, and long nose, indicating it’s telling a lie in the manner of Pinocchio. Like that character, Facebook's design features a wooden nose. May represent lying, a liar, and other concepts of deceit and dishonesty to varying degrees of intensity. Sometimes used to convey disbelief (e.g., You must be kidding) or feeling abashed (e.g., as if caught in the act of lying).

A yellow face, usually shown with closed eyes and raised eyebrows, with saliva drooling from one corner of its mouth. Often used to show desire for a person (sexy, attractive) or object (e.g., delicious food). May also represent someone is tired or sleeping. Not to be confused with 😋 Face Savoring Food or 😪 Sleepy Face. Samsung's design previously featured a startled facial expression.

A sickly-green face with concerned eyes and puffed, often red cheeks, as if holding back vomit. May represent physical illness or general disgust. Not to be confused with 🤮 Face Vomiting. Differs from other smileys conveying sickness, including 🤒 Face With Thermometer (used especially for colds and flus) and 🤕 Face With Head-Bandage (physical injury).

A yellow face with scrunched, X-shaped eyes sneezing or blowing its nose into a white tissue, as if from a cold or allergies. Often depicted with a crumpled-looking mouth. May also represent someone in an emotional state wiping away tears, as at a wedding.

Yee-haw! A yellow smiley wearing a wide-brimmed, brown-leather cowboy hat. Its smile varies across platforms. May convey a sense of exuberance, whimsy, confidence, adventure, or other sentiments. Several vendors, including Apple, feature the same expression as their 😃 Grinning Face With Big Eyes.

A circus or birthday clown displayed with white face makeup, a red nose, exaggerated eyes and smile, and two tufts of hair (red or blue). Commonly used as comment on TikTok or other social media platforms to indicate that a person is foolish, idiotic and/or selfish. May instead describe something that is creepy or scary. Sometimes used as an unflattering alias for Donald Trump.

A heart shaded completely black. May be used to express morbidity, sorrow, or a form of dark humor, but despite the color remains most commonly used for love and affection. Additionally, as with the other color-based hearts, this emoji is often also used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color.
A raised hand, showing the reverse side of the palm. May be paired with the forward-facing raised hand emoji.

A fingers crossed emoji which displays the index (first) finger crossed over the middle (second) finger. Commonly used as a gesture indicating luck, or to show desire of a favorable outcome. This emoji was previously displayed with an additional finger on Samsung devices.

A hand with thumb and little (pinky) finger extended, making a traditional phone-like shape. May be used in conjunction with a face to suggest “call me” (please). Not to be confused with the sign of the horn. Commonly used as a shaka sign, which is a similar gesture at a different orientation.
A fist pointing left, which may be used in conjunction with the right-facing fist to complete a fist-bump gesture.
A fist pointing right, which may be used in conjunction with the left-facing fist to complete a fist-bump gesture.

Two hands performing a handshake gesture, indicating a cordial greeting between friends or associates. As of late 2021's Emoji 14.0 recommendations, this emoji design has multiple skin tone modifier options. Certain platforms did, however, support a small number of single skin tone options for the handshake emoji prior to 2021 (e.g. both Google and Samsung in 2017). View all handshake emojis.
A mobile phone held up to take a selfie (photo of the person holding the phone or camera). Generally represented as a disembodied arm holding a mobile phone.

A hand shown pressing against the head of a person, commonly written as facepalm. Used to display frustration or embarrassment at the ineptitude of a person or situation. May be used in a similar context to the acronym SMH (shaking my head), or in relation to the Picard Facepalm meme.

A person shrugging their shoulders to indicate a lack of knowledge about a particular topic, or a lack of care about the result of a situation. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ Displays as raised shoulders, sometimes in conjunction with raised arms and flat hands. The shrug gesture in text (emoticon / kaomoji) form is known as a shruggie and typed as: ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ The Unicode character Shrug ("Person Shrugging") does not specify a gender, though it was previously shown as a woman on most platforms. See also Woman Shrugging or Man Shrugging.

Male royalty, intended as a gender pair for the princess emoji. Shown as a man with a crown. Not a reference to the musician Prince, however the man singer emoji on WhatsApp does show a character that bears a heavy resemblance to this artist.
A person dressed for a formal occasion, wearing a tuxedo. No gender is specified for this emoji. See also Woman in Tuxedo and Man in Tuxedo.

A pregnant woman holding her round stomach. Sometimes used in jest to represent feeling too full after overeating, as in a "food baby." Variants include 🫄 Pregnant Person and 🫃 Pregnant Man. Twelve modified versions of Apple's pregnant woman emoji design are featured in English artist Damien Hirst's design for the cover artwork of hip-hop artist Drake's 2021 album Certified Lover Boy.
Mother Christmas, more commonly known as Mrs. Claus, is the wife of Santa Claus. Displayed as an older woman with glasses and a festive red and white bonnet. See also: Christmas emoji list.
A man dancing, added as a gender pair for the 💃 Woman Dancing. Shown on most platforms in a 70s-era suit, and one hand in the air in a disco-dancing style.
A person shown in the sport of fencing, with a Rapier-style sword, mask, and protective clothing.

A person doing a cartwheel, representing the sport of gymnastics. In June 2023 this emoji was at the center of a viral trend (Ba’t 🤸 malungkot 🤸 ang 🤸 beshy 🤸 ko?) based on a scene from an episode of the Philippine television drama anthology show Magpakailanman.
Two people in the sport of wrestling.
A person shown in water with a ball, playing the sport of water polo.
A person playing the sport of handball, shown jumping in the air about to throw the ball. Apple's design is shown wearing protective goggles.

A person juggling between three and five colored balls. The person shown in this emoji wears a hat on most major platforms. Early Twitter and Facebook designs previously displayed this emoji as a pair of disembodied hands juggling three colored balls.

A gorilla, the powerful, black-haired great ape. Variously depicted in full profile on all fours facing left or as a friendly, cartoon-styled gorilla face looking straight ahead. Most platforms' designs depict a full gorilla, as a silverback, with strong shoulders and reddish forehead. Twitter’s designs feature a black and gray gorilla face with a neutral expression and prominent forehead and jaw. Google, Samsung, and Facebook’s designs previously featured only a gorilla face. This emoji is considered racist in some contexts, particularly when used to disparage, insult, and abuse people with dark skin, especially Black people.

A friendly, cartoon-styled faced of a fox, the cunning canine, looking straight ahead. Depicted as an orange fox face with a black nose, pointed ears, and shaggy, white cheeks. Often used with an affectionate or playful tone (e.g., slang, foxy). Does not have a full-bodied fox emoji counterpart. Available as an Apple Animoji.

A deer, a fleet-footed, hoofed mammal whose males (bucks, stags) generally have antlers. Variously depicted as a light-brown deer in full profile on all fours facing left or as a deer face looking straight head; both depictions feature large, branched antlers. May be used to represent elk, moose, antelope, or reindeer, especially in connection with Christmas. Most platforms display a deer in full profile. Twitter shows a deer face. Google’s deer previously had a red nose, as Rudolph the Red-nosed Reindeer. Apple and WhatsApp’s deers are white-tailed.

A rhinoceros, a large mammal with one or two massive horns on its nose. Generally shown in light gray with two horns, depicted in full profile on all fours or as a rhinoceros head looking left. Resembles the white or black rhinoceros. Apple, Google, Microsoft, WhatsApp, and Facebook’s designs feature the full animal, while Samsung and Twitter’s designs feature only the rhinoceros' head. Facebook’s design previously featured just the rhinoceros' head, as did Google's.

A bat, the flying mammal of the night. Variously depicted as a brown, black, or gray bat, with wings outspread and pointy ears, facing forward or left. Often used in association with Halloween, vampires, and Batman. Google’s bat was previously purplish in color, bearing two fangs. Samsung’s bat was previously brown, and Facebook’s gray.

A bald eagle, the majestic bird of prey with brown feathers and distinctive white head. Generally depicted facing left, with its wings outspread and talons out, as if swooping down to seize prey. Commonly associated with the United States, whose national emblem is the bald eagle. May be used for other eagles and birds of prey (e.g., hawks). It is also often associated with the Philadelphia Eagles NFL team. Google’s eagle used to have its wings tucked in, as if perched on a branch. Twitter’s design shows only the bust of an eagle. Apple’s 📰 Newspaper features its eagle on its masthead.

Quack! A duck, a waterbird with webbed feet. Depicted as a male (drake) mallard in full profile facing left, standing on its legs with gray and brown feathers, a yellow bill, and its distinctive green head. May be consumed in the form of a 🍗 Poultry Leg. Occasionally used as a substitute for the F-word, due to rhyming and Apple's iPhone autocorrect. Samsung’s design previously featured a yellow rubber ducky.

An owl, the hooting, large-eyed bird. Depicted as a brown owl with its head facing forward. Shown with large, round, gold-rimmed eyes, talons, tucked wings, and horn-like tufts of feathers. May be used to represent wisdom. Available as an Apple Animoji. Once popularly used in connection with the hip-hop artist Drake. Microsoft’s owl previously resembled a barn owl, Samsung’s was purple.

A lizard, a scaly reptile with a long tail. Depicted as a light-green lizard on all fours from above, generally looking left with large eyes, a lightly textured or colored back, and toes outspread, as a gecko. May be used for a variety of wild and pet lizards. Google’s lizard was previously brown.

A shark, a large, stealthy fish with many teeth. Generally depicted as a gray shark in full profile facing left, as a tiger, bull, or great white shark hunting in the water. Shown with a white underside and three gills, its pointed nose and teeth-lined mouth curving down to a sharp dorsal fin and long, pointed tail. Available as an Apple Animoji. Not to be confused with 🐬 Dolphin.

A shrimp (prawn), a small crustacean with a long tail. Generally depicted as a reddish-orange shrimp (as cooked) in full profile facing left, with tiny eyes, many limbs, and its long antennae curling back as its long tail curls in. May be consumed in the form of 🍤 Fried Shrimp or 🥘 Shallow Pan of Food. Often used to represent seafood. The antennae of Apple’s shrimp curls under its body. The body of Facebook’s shrimp is straight. Google and Samsung’s shrimp previously faced right.

A squid, an octopus-like sea animal with ten arms. Generally depicted as a pinkish-orange giant squid, facing forward or angled to the left, with a slender, arrow-like body, small eyes, and two, long arms raised up at its sides. Platforms generally depict six arms. Occasionally used to represent squid as a food item. Not to be confused with 🐙 Octopus, though their applications may overlap. Microsoft, WhatsApp and Twitter’s squid designs are facing forward, as was a previous Google design. Samsung’s squid was previously gray.

A butterfly, a beautiful winged insect whose larva is a caterpillar. Depicted with its wings outspread, as a blue-and-black morpho butterfly or orange-and-black monarch butterfly. May be used to represent a moth and ideas of beauty and happiness. Since December 2023 this emoji has been used to reference the social media platform Bluesky, due to the platform's logo being a blue butterfly. Samsung’s butterfly previously resembled a monarch.

A flower that has wilted, or is dying. Generally depicted as a limp, faded red rose drooping over the to the right on a dried-out, green stem, shedding a petal. May be used to express sad sentiments such as heartbreak, though sometimes with a sense of irony. Ironic use of this emoji spiked in early 2025, especially on TikTok. Sometimes used to represent a rose or other flower, with positive connotations. Nevertheless, not to be confused with 🌹 Rose. WhatsApp's flower suggests a wilted 🌻 Sunflower; Twitter's a 🌷 Tulip, as Microsoft and Samsung's previously did. Facebook's flower was previously orange.

A kiwifruit, or Chinese gooseberry, with its fuzzy, brown skin sliced open to show its light-green flesh, white core, and black seeds. May be associated with New Zealand, whose residents are nicknamed Kiwis, after the bird.
A pear-shaped avocado, sliced in half to show its yellow-green flesh and large brown pit. Ready for toast, guacamole, or millennial jokes.

A whole potato, such as a russet, used for baking, mashing, or frying, shown with a few eyes on its golden-brown skin. Not to be confused with the roasted sweet potato, though their uses may overlap. May be used as an insult, either to disparage a person based on their appearance or perceived lack of intelligence, or to decry low-quality digital content, including blurry images, distorted audio, or pixelated video. Can be used to reference a mash-up in music, though this use case is uncommon.
A whole, bright orange carrot, topped with long green leaves, as if freshly plucked from the garden. Some platforms feature a longer, thinner carrot, others a shorter, more bulbous one.
A long, green cucumber with bumpy skin. Resembles its derived product, a pickle or gherkin, on many platforms, except on Apple and WhatsApp, which depict it with light-green, seed-y slices.

The pod of the peanut, shown in its rounded, grooved, light-brown shell. Apple depicts a pair. Can also be used to reference the use of "peanut" as a term of affection for young children, or to describe an insignificant sum of money ("it cost peanuts"). May also be used for peanut butter as well as other edible nuts (e.g., almonds) or metaphorical ones, including slang for “crazy”, “testicle”, or to nut (ejaculate).
The flaky, golden-brown crescent of a croissant, a breakfast pastry associated with France and Austria. The croissant emoji went viral on Tiktok in January 2023.

The long, thin loaf of a baguette, with scoring on its golden-brown crust. A bread commonly associated with France. May also be used to denote financial success, as per the slang term "let's get this bread".

A stack of breakfast pancakes, topped with a pad of butter and maple syrup oozing down its golden-brown sides, onto a plate on some platforms. Especially popular on Pancake Tuesday. An alternative use for this emoji on TikTok and other platforms: to represent that someone has a flat bottom ('flat as a pancake').
Strips of crispy, fatty, reddish-brown bacon, as fried for breakfast. Depicted as a pair on most platforms.

A flatbread, like pita, stuffed with lettuce, tomato, and/or meat. Resembles a doner kebab, falafel, shawarma, or gyro sandwich, popular in the Middle East and the Mediterranean. Some platforms have red onion and cucumber. Not to be confused with 🫓 Flatbread or 🌯 Burrito.
An egg, displayed as a chicken egg with a white or light brown shell. Commonly used at Easter time. See also: 🍳 Cooking.

A flat, shallow, black pan with side handles, containing saffron-colored rice, vegetables, a leg of poultry, and/or shrimp and lemon slices. Commonly associated with paella, a traditional dish from Spain. May be used for eating, cooking, dining, and meals more generally. Apple's version of this emoji is considered to be representative of the traditional ingredients from Valencia. Samsung previously displayed this emoji as a Korean hot pot.

An undressed garden salad in a bowl with leafy-green lettuce and other ingredients such as tomato, red onion, and black olives. Commonly associated with healthy eating and living. Google previously displayed a hard-boiled egg, removed in 2018 to make the salad vegan-friendly.
A tall glass of white milk, as from a cow but also other mammals, nuts, or plants. Most platforms depict a glass filled near to the brim, but some show a glass half-full—or half-empty.

Two flutes of champagne or sparkling wine being clinked together, as done at a celebratory or convivial toast (“Cheers!”). This emoji tends to spike in popularity during New Year's Eve. Samsung’s design previously suggested two glasses of white wine. Some platforms include stylized links to mark the clinking. See also Clinking Beer Mugs—and Bottle With Popping Cork for a refill.

A short, flat glass, as used for brown liquors like whiskey or Scotch whisky. Apple, Google, Facebook, and WhatsApp serve theirs neat, while other platforms include ice ("on the rocks"). Samsung's glass previously featured the faint initials ONI, an apparent in-company easter egg.

A metal spoon, as used to eat soup, cereal, or ice cream as well as serve food or stir drinks. Positioned at various angles across platforms. May be paired with Fork and Knife, Fork and Knife With Plate, and Bowl With Spoon. In February 2025, this emoji became a symbol of protest among U.S. federal employees against large-scale workforce reductions.
A motor scooter, which may be displayed as any type of motorbike with or without a step-through frame. Distinct from the racing motorcycle, which is used for sport, not transport.
A non-motorized scooter, with two wheels and handles.

A red, octagonal sign, often but not always shown with a white or grey rim. Used in many countries as a stop sign.

Unlike other platforms, Huawei's design for this emoji displays the word "STOP".

A narrow lightweight water vessel that is usually pointed on both ends and made of either wood or plastic.

Generally depicted with a paddle.
A gold medal, given to the person or team who comes first in a competitive sporting event such as a race.
A silver medal, given to the person or team who comes second in a competitive sporting event such as a race.
A bronze medal, given to the person or team who comes third in a competitive sporting event such as a race.
A padded boxing glove, used in the sport of boxing. Usually red.
A white uniform used in marital arts such as judo or karate. Held together using a material belt. Known as keikogi in Japanese.
A goal net where players score points in competitive sporting events. Generally depicted as a goal net used in either field hockey or ice hockey.
A drum shown with drumsticks. A percussion instrument which is likely to be displayed as a snare drum.

A metal shopping cart that you might find in a supermarket or grocery store. The color of the cart's wheels and handle vary by platform. Previous Google designs displayed the cart itself as yellow and orange, while Facebook's cart is red. Most popular around Black Friday and into the Christmas season.
The female version of 👱 Person with Blond Hair.
The male version of 👱 Person with Blond Hair.
The male version of the 🙍 Person Frowning emoji.
The female version of the 🙍 Person Frowning emoji. Currently identical in appearance to the non-gendered base emoji.
The male version of the 🙎 Person With Pouting Face emoji.
The female version of the 🙎 Person With Pouting Face emoji.

A woman with arms crossed forming an ‘X’ to indicate ‘no’ or ‘no good’. This motion is used on the TV game show Deal or No Deal to indicate ‘No Deal’. Intended to be gender-neutral but shown as a woman on most platforms.
A woman with arms crossed forming an ‘X’ to indicate ‘no’ or ‘no good’. This motion is used on the TV game show Deal or No Deal to indicate ‘No Deal’.
The male version of the 🙆 Face With OK Gesture emoji.
The female version of the 🙆 Face With OK Gesture emoji.

A man tipping his hand by his shoulder as if he’s carrying a tray of drinks or flipping his hair.

This emoji is commonly used to express sassiness or sarcasm.

A woman tipping her hand by her shoulder as if she’s carrying a tray of drinks or flipping her hair. This emoji is commonly used to express sassiness or sarcasm. The earlier gender-unspecified version of this emoji, 💁 Person Tipping Hand, was originally depicted as a woman across most platforms.
The man version of the 🙋 Happy Person Raising One Hand emoji.
The female version of the 🙋 Happy Person Raising One Hand emoji. Currently identical in appearance to the non-gendered base emoji.
The male version of the 🙇 Person Bowing Deeply emoji.
The female version of the 🙇 Person Bowing Deeply emoji.
A hand shown pressing against the head of a man, commonly written as facepalm. Used to display frustration or embarrassment at the ineptitude of a person or situation.
A hand shown pressing against the head of a woman, commonly written as facepalm. Used to display frustration or embarrassment at the ineptitude of a person or situation.
A man shrugging his shoulders to indicate a lack of knowledge about a particular topic, or a lack of care about the result of a situation. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯
A woman shrugging her shoulders to indicate a lack of knowledge about a particular topic, or a lack of care about the result of a situation. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯
A man working in the field of health care. This may be used to represent a doctor, nurse, or pharmacist. See also: 👩‍⚕️ Female Health Worker
A woman working in the field of health care. This may be used to represent a doctor, nurse, or pharmacist. See also: 👨‍⚕️ Male Health Worker
A man who is engaged in education. Generally depicted wearing a black graduation gown and cap, and occasionally holding a degree certificate or diploma.
A woman who is engaged in education. Generally depicted wearing a black graduation gown and cap, and occasionally holding a degree certificate or diploma.
A man standing in front of a chalkboard (aka blackboard) with the intention of teaching a class. Often shown holding a 📕 Closed Book or a pointer.
A woman standing in front of a chalkboard (aka blackboard) with the intention of teaching a class. Often shown holding a 📕 Closed Book or a pointer.
A man who presides over court proceedings, wearing the traditional black gown and wielding a gavel.
A woman who presides over court proceedings, wearing the traditional black gown and wielding a gavel.
A man engaged in agriculture, raising living organisms for food or raw materials. Generally depicted as wearing a wide-brimmed hat and holding a crop (such as carrots or corn) or a pitchfork.
A woman engaged in agriculture, raising living organisms for food or raw materials. Generally depicted as wearing a wide-brimmed hat and holding a crop (such as carrots or corn) or a pitchfork.

A man responsible for food preparation wearing a white buttoned chef jacket and toque hat. Usually shown with either a wooden spoon or a skillet frying an egg, though WhatsApp's design is holding a spatula.

A woman responsible for food preparation wearing a white buttoned chef jacket and toque hat. Usually shown with either a wooden spoon or a skillet frying an egg, though WhatsApp's design is holding a spatula.
A man engaged in the construction, maintenance, or repair of machinery. Depicted wearing overalls and holding a wrench. Frequently also shown wearing a billed cap.
A woman engaged in the construction, maintenance, or repair of machinery. Depicted wearing overalls and holding a wrench. Frequently also shown wearing a billed cap.
A man working in a factory setting, depicted as wearing overalls and protective headgear while holding an active welding gun.
A woman working in a factory setting, depicted as wearing overalls and protective headgear while holding an active welding gun.
A man wearing business attire. This may include items such as a shirt, tie, jacket, or headset.
A woman wearing business attire. This may include items such as a shirt, blouse, tie, jacket, or headset.

A man who is studying or has expert knowledge of one or more of the natural or physical sciences. Generally depicted wearing safety goggles and a white lab coat while holding a test tube filled with colorful liquid.

A woman who is studying or has expert knowledge of one or more of the natural or physical sciences. Generally depicted wearing safety goggles and a white lab coat while holding a test tube filled with colorful liquid.
A man behind a computer screen, working in the field of technology. See also: 👩‍💻 Female Technologist
A woman behind a computer screen, working in the field of technology. See also: 👨‍💻 Male Technologist

A man singer or rock star generally displayed with a microphone, and sometimes musical notes. iOS and Android display this emoji as a Bowie-esque figure while WhatsApp appears heavily inspired by Prince.

A woman singer or rock star generally displayed with a microphone, and sometimes musical notes. iOS and Android display this emoji as a Bowie-esque figure while WhatsApp appears heavily inspired by Prince.
A man engaged in the visual art of painting, shown holding a palette and paintbrush.
A woman engaged in the visual art of painting, shown holding a palette and paintbrush.
A man tasked with flying an aircraft, such as an ✈️ Airplane or a 🚁 Helicopter, shown wearing a traditional airline pilot uniform.
A woman tasked with flying an aircraft, such as an ✈️ Airplane or a 🚁 Helicopter, shown wearing a traditional airline pilot uniform.
A male astronaut or cosmonaut shown wearing a space suit and helmet.
A female astronaut or cosmonaut shown wearing a space suit and helmet.
A man professionally tasked with controlling and extinguishing fires.
A woman professionally tasked with controlling and extinguishing fires.
The male version of the 👮 Police Officer emoji. Currently identical in appearance to the non-gendered base emoji.
The female version of the 👮 Police Officer emoji.
The male version of the 🕵 Sleuth or Spy emoji. Currently identical in appearance to the non-gendered base emoji.
The female version of the 🕵 Sleuth or Spy emoji.
The male version of the 💂 Guardsman emoji. Currently identical in appearance to the non-gendered base emoji.
The female version of the 💂 Guardsman emoji.
The male version of the 👷 Construction Worker emoji.
The female version of the 👷 Construction Worker emoji.
The male version of the 👳‍♀️ Woman Wearing Turban emoji.
The female version of the 👳 Man Wearing Turban emoji.
The male version of the 💆 Face Massage emoji.
The female version of the 💆 Face Massage emoji.
The male version of the 💇 Haircut emoji.
The female version of the 💇 Haircut emoji.
The male version of the 🚶 Person Walking emoji.
The female version of the 🚶 Pedestrian emoji.
The male version of the 🏃 Runner emoji.
The female version of the 🏃 Runner emoji.
The male version of the 👯 Woman With Bunny Ears emoji.
A female version of the 👯 People With Bunny Ears emoji.
The male version of the 🏌 Golfer emoji.
The female version of the 🏌 Golfer emoji.
The male version of the 🏄 Surfer emoji.
The female version of the 🏄 Surfer emoji.
The male version of the 🚣 Rowboat emoji.
The female version of the 🚣 Rowboat emoji.
The male version of the 🏊 Swimmer emoji.
The female version of the 🏊 Swimmer emoji.
The male version of the ⛹ Person With Ball emoji.
The female version of the ⛹ Person With Ball emoji.
The male version of the 🏋 Weight Lifter emoji.
The female version of the 🏋 Weight Lifter emoji.
The male version of the 🚴 Bicyclist emoji.
The female version of the 🚴 Bicyclist emoji.
The male version of the 🚵 Mountain Bicyclist emoji.
The female version of the 🚵 Mountain Bicyclist emoji.
A man doing a cartwheel, representing the sport of gymnastics.
A woman doing a cartwheel, representing the sport of gymnastics.
Two men engaged in the sport of wrestling.
Two women engaged in the sport of wrestling.
A man shown in water with a ball, playing the sport of water polo.
A woman shown in water with a ball, playing the sport of water polo.
A man playing the sport of handball, shown jumping in the air about to throw the ball. Apple's design is shown wearing protective goggles.
A woman playing the sport of handball, shown jumping in the air about to throw the ball. Apple's design is shown wearing protective goggles.
A man juggling between three and five colored balls. The person shown in this emoji wears a hat on most major platforms.
A woman juggling between three and five colored balls. The person shown in this emoji wears a hat on most major platforms.
A family with a father and son.
A family with a father and two sons.
A family consisting of a single male parent and one daughter.
A family with a single male parent, one daughter, and one son.
A circle shown with a crossed vertical line beneath it, used as a representation for women. Often used on International Women's Day.
A circle shown with a diagonal arrow pointing out the top-right, used as a representation for men.

A symbol displaying of a rod with a snake entwined around the outside in a downward-spiral shape. Associated with medicine and health care services such as doctors or hospitals. A similar and related symbol called the Caduceus is frequently used in the United States.

A flag with six colors of the rainbow, generally including red, orange, yellow, green, blue and purple. Commonly used by the LGBT movement as a gay pride flag, or simply pride flag and seen at Pride events. In February 2019 misinformation was spread about a so-called "anti-lgbt emoji" which can be created using a combining character to show a black and white glyph like 🚫 on top of the rainbow flag. This is possible with any emoji on supported platforms, in the same way keycaps are combining characters.
The flag for United Nations. May show as the letters UN. This two letter regional indicator pair is an exceptional reservation as part of ISO 3166.

A yellow face with a broad, open smile, showing upper teeth on most platforms, with stars for eyes, as if seeing a beloved celebrity. Color of stars widely varies by platform, though commonly gold or red. May express that someone or something is amazing, fascinating, impressive, or exciting.

A yellow face with its head tilted, its tongue hanging out of a big grin, and wide eyes in a wild, cockeyed expression. Generally used to express silliness. Commonly represents acting goofy, having fun, and partying and is usually used in a positive manner. May be used in reference to someone or something that is off-kilter. Microsoft, and WhatsApp previously displayed a full-toothed grin instead of an open mouth with a protruding tongue, which appeared less silly and more menacing. Google's design used to show the mouth in a grimace, which also read as more disturbing than silly.

A yellow face with a hand covering its mouth. Displays most often with smiling eyes and/or blushing cheeks, suggesting coy laughter or embarrassment, as if cheekily saying Oops! Prior to the release of iOS 15.4 in March 2022, Apple's design featured simple, open eyes, suggesting someone gasping Oh my! in serious surprise, shock, concern, or apology. This same update assigned Apple's original 🤭 design to Emoji 14.0's new 🫢 Face with Open Eyes and Hand Over Mouth emoji. May be used to similar effect as 🙊 Speak-No-Evil Monkey. See also 🤐 Zipper-Mouth Face. Joins 🤗 Hugging Face, 🤔 Thinking Face, and 🤫 Shushing Face as one of the few smileys featuring hands. Facebook's design previously featured open eyes, though an earlier version had smiling eyes like those in the vendor's current design.

A yellow face placing an index finger over pursed lips, as if issuing Shh! or Shush! for silence. Some platforms feature raised eyebrows. Apple’s design suggests the face is tilting back slightly. May convey silence, quiet, secrecy, and discreetness. May also create a sense of buzz and anticipation, e.g., an exclusive sneak peek or news scoop. May also be combined with one of the 🧏 Deaf Person emojis to reference "mewing". See also 🤐 Zipper-Mouth Face. Joins 🤗 Hugging Face, 🤔 Thinking Face, and 🤭 Face With Hand Over Mouth as one of the few smileys featuring hands.

A yellow face with a flat, neutral mouth and furrowed eyebrows, its left raised higher than its right. Conveys a wide variety of sentiments, including suspicion, skepticism, concern, consideration, disbelief, and disapproval. Its expression has notably been likened to the signature look of comedian Stephen Colbert as well as actor/wrestler Dwayne “The Rock” Johnson.
A yellow face with scrunched, X-shaped eyes spewing bright-green vomit. May represent physical illness or disgust, more intensely so than 🤢 Nauseated Face.

A yellow face with an open mouth, the top of its head exploding in the shape of a brain-like mushroom cloud. A visual form of the expression mind blown, it may represent such emotions as shock, awe, amazement, and disbelief. Apple’s design features the same expression as its 😦 Frowning Face With Open Mouth.

A yellow face with furrowed eyebrows wearing a monocle. Usually depicted with a small, intent frown and head slightly upturned, as if in careful inspection. May show that someone is pondering, considering, or questioning something, sometimes with a sense of skeptical or ironic observation or encouraging a closer look at some content. May convey a sense of sophistication or smug intelligence, e.g., smarty-pants.

An angry-red face with a black bar and white grawlixes covering its mouth, indicating it's swearing or being vulgar. Grawlixes are typographical symbols (e.g., @#$%&!) representing swear words or obscenities. Often used to convey an outburst of anger, frustration, or rage. Most platforms feature the same eyes as on their 😠 Angry Face and 😡 Enraged Face.

An orange heart emoji, often used alongside other colored hearts. As with the other color-based hearts, this emoji is often also used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color. This emoji is mentioned in the 2025 hit Netflix show Adolescence. Learn more here.
The gesture for “I love you” in American Sign Language, shown as a raised pinky (little) finger, index finger, and an extended thumb.

Two hands held out together with open palms facing up, in a slightly cupped manner, as if expecting an object to be placed within them.

May also be used to represent an open book in American Sign Language (ASL), or the gesture used by followers of Islam when praying.
A human brain, shown in pink on most platforms. Used to indicate thinking or the human mind. On platforms such as TikTok this emoji can have an alternative NSFW meaning.
A child with no gender specified. This emoji may be used to talk about children in a gender-inclusive way. Variants include 👧 Girl and 👦 Boy.
An adult with no gender specified. This emoji may be used to talk about adults in a gender-inclusive way. Variants include 👩 Woman and 👨 Man.

A person with a beard. This emoji may be used to talk about bearded people in a gender-inclusive way. It was approved in 2017, initially intended to have a male presentation. Gendered variants of this emoji were approved three years later, leading to this emoji's design being made more neutral in appearance by all major vendors. Variants include 🧔‍♂️ Man with a Beard and 🧔‍♀️ Woman with a Beard, both approved in 2020.

An older adult with no gender specified. This emoji may be used to talk about older adults in a gender-inclusive way. Variants include 👴 Older Man or 👵 Older Woman. See also 🧑‍🦳 Person with White Hair, which is similar, though is shown with white hair and without wrinkles on most platforms.
A person (generally depicted as a woman) wearing a headscarf. While the type of  headscarf is not specified, this is most commonly displayed as a woman wearing a hijab.

A woman shown breastfeeding a baby, sometimes looking down to the infant and smiling. This emoji supports skin tone modifiers, which apply to the mother. The head of the baby is recommended to be hidden to avoid a situation where the skin tone of the baby would only correlate to the skin tone of the mother. See 🧑‍🍼 Person Feeding Baby for bottle feeding instead of breastfeeding.
A person who wields magical powers derived from supernatural or occult sources.

A man who wields magical powers derived from supernatural or occult sources.

May also be referred to as a wizard, warlock, or sorcerer.
A woman who wields magical powers derived from supernatural or occult sources. May also be referred to as a witch, enchantress, or sorceress.

A magical humanoid creature found in myths and fantasy stories. Generally depicted as having insect-inspired wings, it can also be assumed to be quite diminutive in size. This emoji supports skin tones, and variations that are female or male.

A magical humanoid creature found in myths and fantasy stories. Generally depicted as being diminutive in size and having insect-inspired wings. Previously within Windows 11 this Light Skin Tone emoji erroneously displayed the same design as 🧚 Fairy without a skin tone modifier.
A magical male creature found in myths and fantasy stories. Generally depicted as having insect-inspired wings, it can also be assumed to be quite diminutive in size.
A magical female creature found in myths and fantasy stories. Generally depicted as having insect-inspired wings, it can also be assumed to be quite diminutive in size.

A vampire shown wearing a dark cape, and with pointed fangs. This emoji supports skin tones, and variations that are female or male. May be used to call someone an "energy vampire", i.e. a person whose actions leave others exhausted or drained of energy
A skin tone modifier variant of the 🧛 Vampire emoji.
A skin tone modifier variant of the 🧛 Vampire emoji.
A skin tone modifier variant of the 🧛 Vampire emoji.
A skin tone modifier variant of the 🧛 Vampire emoji.
A skin tone modifier variant of the 🧛 Vampire emoji.
A male vampire shown wearing a dark cape, and with pointed fangs.
A female vampire shown wearing a dark cape, and with pointed fangs.
A merperson who may be referred to as merfolk or merpeople in plural. May be used for the display of a mermaid, mergirl, merwoman, or merman. Occasional shown wielding a trident.
The male version of the 🧜 Merperson emoji.
The female version of the 🧜 Merperson emoji.

A mythical creature with pointed ears and a human-like face, originating in folklore. While depictions of elves vary across cultures and traditions, this emoji's design is heavily influenced by the portrayal of elves popularized in modern high fantasy literature, particularly The Lord of the Rings. As such, most vendors display the creature wearing elegant robes and often wearing an ornate headpiece. Even still, this emoji may be used to discuss Santa's helpers, especially around Christmas.
A male creature with pointed ears and a human-like face.
A female creature with pointed ears and a human-like face.

A supernatural being, which is generally shown to be imprisoned within a bottle or lamp. May be capable of granting wishes when summoned. Variations exist for a female genie or male genie. Several vendors' design for this emoji is highly reminiscent of The Genie character from Disney's Aladdin films.
A supernatural male being, which is generally shown to be imprisoned within a bottle or lamp. May be capable of granting wishes when summoned.
A supernatural female being, which is generally shown to be imprisoned within a bottle or lamp. May be capable of granting wishes when summoned.

A reanimated human, often found in works of horror fiction. May have a female or male appearance. May be used to refer to someone who appears listless, apathetic, or unresponsive to their surroundings. May also be used to refer to a person who attempts to resume communications after previously ghosting out of a conversation.
A reanimated human man, often found in works of horror fiction.
A reanimated human woman, often found in works of horror fiction.
A person in a sauna, usually with a towel or robe and sometimes holding a ladle for pouring water on hot stones to create the steamy environment. Popular in Finland, where people sauna in the nude.
A man in a sauna, usually with a towel or robe and sometimes holding a ladle for pouring water on hot stones to create the steamy environment.

A woman in a sauna, usually with a towel or robe and sometimes holding a ladle for pouring water on hot stones to create the steamy environment.

Apple and Samsung's designs are also wearing a towel around their head.

A rock climber, shown climbing up a rock formation. Some platforms show the climber with a helmet and/or rope. The Emojipedia Sample image was created with assistance from World Champion Rock Climber Sasha DiGiulian. Variations exist for 🧗‍♀️ Woman Climbing and 🧗‍♂️ Man Climbing.
A male rock climber, shown climbing up a rock formation. Some platforms show the climber with a helmet, and/or rope. Variations exist for 🧗‍♀️ Woman Climbing and 🧗 Person Climbing.
A female rock climber, shown climbing up a rock formation. Some platforms show the climber with a helmet, and/or rope. Variations exist for 🧗‍♂️ Man Climbing and 🧗 Person Climbing.

A sitting person with their eyes closed and their legs crossed in the lotus position. 

Can be used to broadly represent yoga, meditation, relaxation, or calmness.

A sitting man with their eyes closed and their legs crossed in the lotus position. 

Can be used to broadly represent yoga, meditation, relaxation, or calmness.

A sitting woman with their eyes closed and their legs crossed in the lotus position. 

Can be used to broadly represent yoga, meditation, relaxation, or calmness.

A zebra, a horse-like mammal with black-and-white stripes. Variously depicted in full profile on all fours facing left or as a zebra head facing left with a short mane. Not to be confused with 🐎 Horse. Some vendors implement a similar face as their 🐴 Horse Face. Apple, Microsoft, WhatsApp, Samsung, and Facebook’s designs feature the full animal; Google and Twitter's designs feature a head with a short mane and black muzzle. Facebook’s design previously featured only a zebra head, as did Samsung's.

A giraffe, the tallest animal on Earth, with spots and a long neck. Generally depicted in yellow or tan in full profile on all fours facing left, with distinctive brown spots and small, horn-like structures. Samsung’s designs feature a giraffe face looking straight ahead. Facebook’s design previously featured only a giraffe face, as did Microsoft's.

A hedgehog. A small, spiny mammal sometimes kept as a pet. Generally depicted in full profile on all fours facing left, with a round, brown body covered with spines and a light-brown face and underside. Sometimes used to represent a porcupine or echidna. Twitter's design has always been a hedgehog facing forward. Google's design originally featured a hedgehog facing forward, though it was changed to full profile with Android 11.0. Facebook’s design previously featured a hedgehog on its back, rolled up in a ball.

A sauropod, a massive, plant-eating dinosaur with a long neck and tail. Depicted as a blue, gray, or green sauropod, as a brachiosaurus, apatosaurus/brontosaurus, or diplodocus. Shown in full profile on all fours facing left. May be used to represent various dinosaurs. See also 🦖 T-Rex. May also be used to call a person a dinosaur, i.e. imply that they are old-fashioned or out-of-touch with modern sentiments. Apple, Google and Samsung's sauropods resemble a brachiosaurus. Samsung’s sauropod was previously green, Facebook’s previously displayed only a green head.

A Tyrannosaurus rex, a massive, meat-eating dinosaur with huge jaws, tiny arms, and a long tail. Depicted as a green tyrannosaur standing on its hind lefts facing left, often with a textured back, sharp teeth, and clawed toes. May be used to represent various dinosaurs, including raptors. See also 🦕 Sauropod. May also be used to call a person a dinosaur, i.e. imply that they are old-fashioned or out-of-touch with modern sentiments. Available as an Apple Animoji. Google’s T-rex used to look somewhat like a velociraptor, though the design has since changed. Samsung’s T-Rex was previously red, Microsoft's brown, and Facebook’s only a green head with open jaws.

A cricket, a hopping insect that makes a chirping sound. Depicted as a brown or green cricket in full profile on its six legs facing left, with long antennae and large, bent back legs. May resemble or be used to represent a grasshopper (including locusts) and other bugs. May also be used to represent metaphorical crickets, or "silence," as of a disapproving or uninterested audience. Not to be confused with 🏏 Cricket Game, the sport. Google's cricket was previously green.

The hairy shell of a tropical coconut, cracked in half to show its milky-white meat. Google previously displayed a whole coconut alongside a half-shell. During the summer of 2024 this emoji became associated with then-Vice President of the Untied States Kamala Harris, referencing a viral clip of a speech made in May 2023 where she stated: "You think you just fell out of a coconut tree? You exist in the context of all in which you live and what came before you.”
A rich green, tree-like head or floret of broccoli.
The heart-shaped twist of a hard or soft golden-brown pretzel, seasoned with grains of salt. A snack commonly associated with Germany.
A cut of uncooked red meat, as a T-bone or rib-eye steak, with the light, white marbling of fat. May be used for sexual slang.
A sandwich, as eaten at lunch, made with lettuce, tomato, and cheese on slices of white or wheat bread. Apple, Google, and WhatsApp add a deli meat that resembles ham.

A bowl with a silver spoon inside, as used to eat cereal or soup. Bowl color varies across platforms, as do contents, though most are empty. WhatsApp's bowl contains tomato soup, while Google's previously contained breakfast cereal.
A can or tin of food, depicted as tomatoes or a generic green vegetable. May be also used to represent sauce or soup.

A dumpling of dough and filling, as folded and pinched closed for steaming or frying. Associated with cuisines around the world, including China (jiaozi), Japan (gyoza or dango), Poland (pierogi), and Spain and Latin America (empanada). Facebook's design previously resembled a xiaolongbao, a Chinese soup dumpling.

A golden-brown, crescent-shaped, vanilla-flavored fortune cookie. Usually depicted with a strip of paper—on which a wise saying, lucky numbers, or Chinese vocabulary is written—peaking out of its hollow shell. Given at the end of meals at Chinese restaurants in the West.

A tall, folded, paper carton, usually white, as used for takeout/takeaway food at Western Chinese restaurants. Most platforms depict chopsticks inside its open lid, labeled with a red, multi-tiered, traditional Chinese building. Also called an oyster pail.

A baked dish with a pastry crust, filled with sweet or savory ingredients. Appearance widely varies by platform. Apple depicts a whole pie in a tin, its crimped crust scored to let out steam. WhatsApp and Twitter's designs depict a slice of cherry pie. Google's design previously showed a slice of pumpkin pie, as served at Thanksgiving.

A drinking cup with a straw. Depicted on many platforms as a disposable cup with a lid and bendy straw, as used to serve soft drinks at fast-food restaurants. May be used for a range of non-alcoholic beverages, including milkshakes, smoothies, juice, and to-go beverages. Color and design vary by platform. Twitter's design suggests a glass of water, while Samsung's previously displayed a Slightly Smiling Face on a red label.

A pair of equal-length chopsticks, an eating utensil used throughout East Asia. Design and color vary widely by platform, though often red or wood-colored and with tips angled together. Featured in many platforms' Steaming Bowl of Food and Takeout Box. A counterpart to utensils such as Fork and Knife and Spoon.
A flying saucer, sometimes referred to as an Unidentified Flying Object (UFO). Previously shown on some platforms with an alien at the controls and/or a beam of light emitting from the base.
A sled, otherwise known as a toboggan or sledge.
A curling stone used in the sport of curling. Generally depicted with a red handle, though WhatsApp's design features a blue handle.
A knitted wool scarf, generally worn for warmth. Colored red across most emoji design vendors.

A pair of gloves, generally worn for warmth, shown as being made of kitted wool by most vendors. The colors also vary across different vendors.

WhatsApp's gloves appear to be made of dyed leather.
A winter jacket, shown in a variety of colors and styles.

A pair of socks, generally used to keep one's feet warm and protected. Generally depicted as two matching socks with a block color and one or more lines around where the socks would cover the wearer's ankles. JoyPixel's design previously featured a 💩 Pile of Poo emoji pattern.

A plain soft hat with a rounded crown and a stiff bill. Most often shown in a shade of blue and displayed at an angle to clearly display its outwards- protruding bill.

Regularly associated with the slang term "capping", meaning "lying". Responding to a message with a single 🧢 emoji is viewable as an accusation of lying (“cap”) while stating "no 🧢" ("no cap") is intended to emphasize the truthfulness of a statement.
The flag for England, a country in the United Kingdom. May show as the letters gbeng.
The flag for Scotland, a country in the United Kingdom. May show as the letters gbsct.
The flag for Wales, a country in the United Kingdom. May show as the letters gbwls.

A yellow face with smiling eyes, a closed smile, rosy cheeks, and several hearts floating around its head. Expresses a range of happy, affectionate feelings, especially being in love. The placement of the hearts varies slightly by platform. Apple's design features the same expression as its ☺️ Smiling Face emoji design.

A reddish-orange face with furrowed eyebrows, tongue stuck out, and beads of sweat, as if overheated from high temperatures. Number and position of sweat droplets vary by platforms. May also represent physical attractiveness (slang, hot). Most platforms feature expressions that are variations on 😰 Anxious Face With Sweat or 😥 Sad but Relieved Face.

An icy-blue face with gritted teeth usually depicted with icicles clinging to its cheeks or jaw, as if frozen from extreme cold. May also represent unfriendliness (slang, cold) or excellence (slang, cool or chill). Apple’s design features the same expression as its 😬 Grimacing Face. Huawei's design has a chipped 🦷 Tooth.

A yellow face with a crumpled mouth and a cockeyed expression, as if tired and emotional from inebriation or smitten with love. Depicted with raised or furrowed eyebrows and at least one eye half-open. WhatsApp's design features a tongue hanging out. Meaning widely varies, but commonly conveys intoxication or infatuation. Its dazed expression may also represent such feelings or states as bewilderment, irritation, disgust, exhaustion, wackiness, or complete satisfaction.

A yellow face with a party hat blowing a party horn as confetti floats around its head. Used for celebrating joyous occasions (such as New Year's Eve or World Emoji Day) and enjoying good times more generally. Apple’s design features the same expression as its 😚 Kissing Face With Closed Eyes.

A yellow face with furrowed eyebrows, a small frown, and large, “puppy dog” eyes, as if begging, pleading, or yearning (possibly even in a NSFW manner, depending on the context). May also represent adoration or feeling touched by a loving gesture. Huawei's design for this emoji includes a pair of 🙏 Folded Hands. At its peak the Pleading Face was the third most popular emoji used on Twitter, and was the most commonly found emoji in tweets that include hearts. Used in sequence with pointing hands to indicate a bashful or shy pose (🥺👉👈) particularly on TikTok.
A human leg, shown detached from a human body. Displayed from the thigh and includes the foot.
A human foot shown with five toes and may include part or all of the ankle. Shown on some platforms as the sole of a foot.
A single tooth, like those found in your mouth. Shown as a premolar across all major emoji vendors.
A bone which may be used for a dog to chew on, or as a part of the human body. The type of bone is not specified. May be used to represent the NSFW term "to bone".
The male version of 🧑‍🦰 Person with Red Hair.
The male version of 🧑‍🦱 Person with Curly Hair.
The male version of 🧑‍🦳 Person with White Hair.
The male version of 🧑‍🦲 Bald Person.
The female version of 🧑‍🦰 Person with Red Hair.
The female version of 🧑‍🦱 Person with Curly Hair.
The female version of 🧑‍🦳 Person with White Hair.

A woman with a bald head. Can be used to represent a bald woman or a woman with a shaved head. May also be used to represent a woman experiencing hair loss from chemotherapy, alopecia, or other medical treatments or conditions. Variants include 🧑‍🦲 Bald Person and 👨‍🦲 Bald Man.

A person who wields abilities beyond those of ordinary people and is dedicated to protecting the public. Generally depicted as wearing a colorful domino mask and a cape. This base emoji does not specify a gender, but is used to create the emojis for Man Superhero and Woman Superhero. The Supervillain is the nemesis of this emoji.

A man who wields abilities beyond those of ordinary people and is dedicated to protecting the public. Generally depicted as wearing a colorful domino mask and a cape. The Supervillain is the nemesis of this emoji.

A woman who wields abilities beyond those of ordinary people and is dedicated to protecting the public. Generally depicted as wearing a colorful domino mask and a cape. The Supervillain is the nemesis of this emoji.

A person who wields abilities beyond those of ordinary people who, unlike their nemesis the Superhero, uses their powers for evil. This base emoji does not specify a gender, but is used to create the emojis for Man Supervillain and Woman Supervillain. Google's design is similar to that of Mr. Sinister from the X-Men Marvel comics.

A man who wields abilities beyond those of ordinary people who, unlike their nemesis the Superhero, uses their powers for evil. Google's design is similar to that of Mr. Sinister from the X-Men Marvel comics.

A woman who wields abilities beyond those of ordinary people who, unlike their nemesis the Superhero, uses their powers for evil. Google's design is similar to that of Mr. Sinister from the X-Men Marvel comics.

A raccoon, a nocturnal mammal with a mask around its eyes. Generally depicted as a friendly, cartoon-styled, gray raccoon face looking straight ahead, with black-and-white markings around its eyes and pointed ears and cheeks.

Apple and WhatsApp’s designs feature a raccoon in full profile on all fours facing left with a striped, bushy tail.

A llama, a long-necked, camel-like animal, native to South America and used for transport and wool. Depicted as a shaggy white, light-brown, or multicolored llama in full profile on all fours facing left. May be used to represent an alpaca or related animals.

A hippopotamus, a squat water mammal with huge jaws. Generally depicted in gray or tan in full profile facing left.

Google’s design used to feature a purple, cartoon-styled hippopotamus face. Facebook’s hippopotamus is opening massive jaws, revealing tusks.

A kangaroo, a marsupial with a large tail and legs. Depicted in yellowish-brown in full profile facing left with large, pointed ears, shown either resting on its hind legs and tail or jumping. Commonly used in connection with Australia, where the animal is found.

A badger, a stocky mammal in the weasel family with a long, pointed head. Generally depicted in full profile on all fours facing left, with a gray coat, black-and-white-striped face, and short tail.

Google’s design used to feature a friendly, cartoon-styled black-and-white badger face. Facebook’s badger is sitting on its hind legs.

A swan, a waterbird with white feathers and a long neck. Depicted in full profile facing left, with a curving neck, orange bill, black eye marking, and wings and legs tucked in, as if gliding in water.

May be used to represent a goose or, metaphorically, love, grace, and beauty.

A peacock, the male bird that displays a large, fan-like, iridescent tale. Depicted facing forward standing on its legs, with a blue body and green tail feathers outspread.

Sometimes used to suggest something is beautiful or proud. Also sometimes used to accent a peacock-like color or pattern.

A parrot, a brightly colored bird known for its ability to mimic speech. Depicted in full profile facing left. Resembles a green lovebird with red and yellow wings on some platforms and a scarlet macaw with blue and yellow wings on others. Can be used to represent various parrots or birds in general. May also be used to talk about mimicking. Facebook’s parrot is orange with blue-tipped wings. Google's parrot was previously a scarlet macaw perched on a branch.

A lobster, a large crustacean with a prominent tail and pincers. Depicted as a reddish-orange lobster (as cooked) from above, with a long body and tail, short, tentacle-like eyes, and ten legs, the top of which are very large pincers. Often used to represent lobster as food as well as in connection to the US state of Maine. In its release year of 2018, Emojipedia’s original sample image was criticized as anatomically incorrect but was shortly after resolved. That year, the transgender community embraced the lobster as a symbol for their efforts for Transgender Flag emoji. Samsung, WhatsApp, and Facebook’s lobsters are depicted at an angle.

A mosquito, a type of bloodsucking fly. Depicted as a brown or black mosquito on its six, long legs, with wings, long abdomen, and needle-like mouth. Variously shown from above or facing left. May be used to represent various insects, other bugs and bug bites, and insect-borne diseases (e.g., malaria). May also be used for metaphorical pests. Facebook’s mosquito has a red abdomen, as if filled with blood.

A microbe, as a bacterium grown in a 🧫 Petri Dish or observed under a 🔬 Microscope. Generally depicted as a squiggly, single-celled microorganism with prominent cilia. Color, shape, and position vary across platforms. Commonly used to represent bacteria, viruses, and germs and disease more generally. In 2020, this emoji became primarily used in reference to Coronavirus / COVID-19. Apple's version of this emoji most closely represents a virus, while others from Samsung, Microsoft and Twitter appear as bright green bacteria. Other versions of this emoji also appear mainly as bacteria: Facebook's is indigo, and WhatsApp’s purple. Google’s design previously displayed five microbes in different, bright colors.
The ripe fruit of a tropical mango. Variously depicted in shades of yellow, red, orange, and green with a single, green leaf and stem.

A head of a rich green leaf vegetable, usually shown with white stalks. May be used to represent a variety of greens, including romaine lettuce, chard, and Chinese cabbage like bok choy, as commonly cooked in Asian cuisines.

The brown bread of a bagel, shown sliced in two halves. Some platforms depict seeds, as sesame or poppy, and a schmear of cream cheese, with the bagel assembled as a sandwich. May resemble the Doughnut at small sizes. After complaints, Apple updated the bagel emoji design during the iOS 12.1 beta cycle.

A clear glass shaker of salt with a silver cap, as paired with pepper to season food when eating at a restaurant.

May be used to represent "being salty" (feeling bitter, upset, or annoyed).

The round, golden-brown pastry of a Chinese mooncake, a traditional delicacy and lunar symbol of the Mid-Autumn Festival. Many platforms feature a design or character imprinted on the crust, and depict a slice cut out to show a brown paste with a duck egg yolk inside. Twitter displays the Chinese character for “fall/autumn” or “harvest” (秋) on top.

An individual cupcake in a liner topped with a swirl of frosting and sprinkles. The style of cupcake widely varies across platforms. The cake may be sponge or chocolate, the frosting pink or white, and the sprinkles rainbow or red.

A magnetic compass, as used for navigation. Generally depicted in a silver or gold case with a compass rose and a red-tipped needle. Commonly used for various content concerning traveling and exploring as well as metaphorical compasses (e.g., moral compass). Facebook’s markings include the initials of the four cardinal directions, north, south, east, and west. Not to be confused with various clock or timepiece emojis.

A red brick or bricks. Depicted in a loose stack, a single object with holes, or as built into wall, as of a house, school, or other structure. Commonly used for discussing building and construction. May also be used to reference blockades or obstructions, either literal or intangible. It may also be used in further figurative contexts, such as describing extremely cold weather (“it’s brick”), a non-functional electronic device (“bricked”), or in sexual slang ("bricked up").

A skateboard emoji, usually showing the board from the top. Twitter's design shows the under-side of the board, as did a previous Microsoft design. Emojipedia's sample image was modelled after Tony Hawk's skateboard.

A suitcase or bag, as used for traveling. Most platforms depict gray or blue rolling luggage with an extended handle. Commonly used for various content concerning traveling or taking trips, whether for business or leisure. Apple’s design features an old-fashioned, leather, trunk-styled case with graphic luggage labels/stickers, not to be confused with 💼 Briefcase or 👜 Handbag. Google and Facebook also include such stickers. May be stored in a 🛅 Coin Locker or inspected at 🛃 Customs.

A firecracker, as lit on Chinese New Year, New Year's Eve, or Independence Day. Depicted as a red tube with a burning fuse, sometimes lined with gold rings at its top and base. Often used with 🎆 Fireworks and 🎇 Sparkler for various celebrations and holidays. Also applied to figurative senses of fire, e.g., slang hot, on fire (“excellent”). This emoji is possibly alluded to in the 2025 hit Netflix show Adolescence. Learn more here. While it may resemble a stick of dynamite on some platforms, several vendor designs, such as Google and Twitter's, suggest the emoji is modeled after traditional Chinese firecrackers, as are strung together and lit on such occasions as Chinese New Year.

A red envelope, as gifted with money on Chinese New Year or on other joyous occasions, such as weddings, in Chinese and some other Asian cultures around the world. Depicted as a red, vertical envelope with a gold design, typically featuring the Chinese character 福 (fú, “good fortune, luck, happiness"). Google’s design previously featured the character upside down, indicating “good luck arrives.” Often used to celebrate and wish good fortune on Chinese New Year (Lunar New Year, Spring Festival). Also used to represent gifts, celebration, Chinese culture, and the color red more generally.

A softball, which is differentiated from a baseball by its size (it is larger, though hard to tell in emoji form) and color (yellow, not white).

May be used to reference giving someone a "softball question", a question that is easy to answer.
A flying disc, more commonly known as a frisbee. Used in the sport of Ultimate or disc golf.
A stick and ball used in the sport of lacrosse. The ball is usually depicted as either orange or white, while the stick's color varies across emoji designs.

A single piece of a jigsaw puzzle, shown with two tabs and two blanks.

Usually shown as a plain green puzzle piece, though color and imagery does vary.

A classic teddy bear, as snuggled by a child when going to sleep. Depicted as a brown, stuffed toy bear, shown seated with its arms to the sides, hind paw pads facing forward, and a friendly smile on its face. Google, WhatsApp, and Twitter's designs include a ribbon around the neck, while Facebook's is wearing a bow tie. Commonly used to convey something or someone is cute or cuddly (e.g., teddy bear as a term of endearment) as well as other warm, loving sentiments (e.g., get well soon). May also be used for various content concerning toys and children more generally. Not to be confused with 🐻 Bear Face, though their applications may overlap.
A single black pawn used in the game of chess.

A spool of thread, as used for sewing. Thread color varies across platforms, though often depicted in red or blue and on a wooden spool. Sometimes shown with an end unraveling. Commonly used for various content concerning sewing, knitting, arts and crafts, clothing and fashion, and metaphorical threads (e.g., a discussion thread online). WhatsApp and Microsoft's designs includes a needle.

A ball of yarn, as used to knit a scarf. Color varies across platforms, but often depicted in green, blue, or magenta and shown with an end unraveling. Sometimes depicted with a pair of knitting needles stuck in the ball. Commonly used for various content concerning knitting and needlework (e.g., sewing, crocheting), clothing and fashion, arts and crafts, cold weather, and cats.

Clear safety goggles. When this emoji was approved in 2018 it was implied to be safety goggles rather than swimming goggles. A year later 🤿 Diving Mask, which is similar in design but used to represent swimming goggles rather than safety goggles, was approved.
A white coat worn in a science laboratory.
A style of boot commonly worn on long walks or for hiking. Generally distinct from other footwear-related emojis by the considerable grip on the sole of the shoe.
A flat shoe, in a style generally worn by women. More practical than a high-heeled shoe.

An abacus, an ancient tool used to count and calculate by moving beads. Depicted as a wooden frame with four or more rows or columns of variously positioned and colored beads. Used for various content concerning mathematics and science (education) as well as calculations, counting, and numbers more generally. Designs from Apple and Facebook resemble a Chinese abacus (suanpan), as did a previous Microsoft design. By one reckoning, Apple’s red-beaded design displays the number 108 and Emojipedia's, 12,031,981.

A white paper receipt, as proof of payment, and shown flat or curled. May be used for other financial documents (e.g., invoice, tax form). May also be used for the slang receipts, or "evidence” or “confirmation” of some feat or controversy. Some vendors feature easter eggs. Apple’s design, for instance, displays the date of July 17 (World Emoji Day); items referencing its 1997–2002 Crazy Ones/Think Different ad campaign (misfits, square pegs, round holes); and a balance $0.00.

A red box for holding and transporting tools, such as a hammer and wrench. Generally depicted as latched shut with silver hardware and a black handle. Commonly used for literal or metaphorical tools, toolkits, and building. WhatsApp's design includes a hammer in front. Google’s design was previously shown as open with two wrenches and a pair of pliers.

A horseshoe magnet, as used to pick up iron. Depicted at various angles in red with silver-tipped poles. Commonly used for various content concerning literal and figurative magnetism and attraction. May also be used in various science-related contexts more generally. Twitter’s design features two electric bolts coming from its poles. WhatsApp’s horseshoe is half blue, denoting an opposite magnetic pole.

A test tube, as used to conduct chemical experiments in a laboratory. Depicted as a clear cylinder, open at one end and containing a green liquid. Positioned at a 45° angle.

May be used for various content concerning chemistry and science more generally. May also represent other liquids, such as potions or medicines, as well metaphorical laboratories and experiments.

Some platforms include volume markings or display the liquid as bubbling. WhatsApp’s design features a blue liquid.

A petri dish, as used to culture microbes. Depicted as a clear, shallow cylinder with a red, blue, or green growth medium, such as agar, with splotches of variously colored cells, like bacteria. May be used for various content concerning biology and science more generally. May also be used to represent germs and other microorganisms. Samsung’s design features a lid, while Google’s design previously featured a dropper.

The double helix of DNA, the genetic blueprint for life. Color and orientation vary across platforms, but positioned at a 45° angle and in multiple, bright colors to represent the molecule’s spiraling, ladder-like structure. Can be used for various content concerning biology, genetics, and science more generally. May be used for various content concerning literal or figurative life and evolution. May also be used as sexual slang.

A bottle of lotion for the skin, such as moisturizer or sunscreen (sunblock). May be used for other hygienic liquids, including shampoo and body wash, as well as beauty products. Appearance varies across platforms, but commonly depicted in white and gold colors. Some designs also include a droplet icon on the bottle. Most platforms feature a bottle with a pump, though others previously displayed a cylinder with a cap.

A silver safety pin or clip, as used to fasten fabric. Generally shown clasped at a 45° angle, with its spring at the lower left. May be used for various content concerning arts, crafts, and sewing. Not to be confused with 📎 Paperclip.

A traditional broom, as used for sweeping—or ridden by a witch. Shown at a 45° angle, with a wooden handle and yellow bristles at the lower left. Commonly used for various content concerning cleaning, brushing, and figurative sweeps (e.g., in sports or awards). Not to be confused with 🖌️ Paintbrush.

A basket, as used for storing or carrying such things as food or clothes. Appearance widely varies across platforms but generally depicted as woven from wicker with one or more handles. Commonly used to represent doing laundry or having a picnic. Apple and WhatsApp’s designs, featuring a white cloth, suggest a bread or picnic basket. Samsung’s design displays green fabric, as knitted from yarn. Microsoft’s design previously suggested a laundry basket by holding a blue garment or cloth. Not to be confused with 🗑️ Wastebasket.

A roll of paper, as toilet paper (toilet tissue). May also be a roll of kitchen/paper towels. Depicted at various angles, with a sheet unfurling. Commonly used for toilet paper but may also be used for various content concerning toilets, going to the bathroom, bathrooms, cleaning, or paper more generally.

A bar of soap, as used in the shower, bath or for hand washing. Generally shown with lathered bubbles. Depicted in various colors, often pink, and at different angles. Commonly used for various content concerning bathing, washing, and cleaning. May be used to represent the opposite of dirt or being dirty. Recommended for use to prevent the spread of COVID-19. Could also be used to refer to the slang term for money used in a bribe.

A peanut-shaped sponge, as used for cleaning or bathing. Generally depicted in yellow and at different angles across platforms. Commonly used for various content concerning bathing, washing, and cleaning. May also be used to evoke the metaphor of the brain as a sponge, absorbing knowledge or soaking up information.

A fire extinguisher, as used to put out small fires. Depicted as a red tank with a black hose and pressure gauge. Most platforms include an image of a flame on a white label. Commonly used for various content concerning fire safety, emergencies, and literal and figurative fires.

A nazar, an eye-shaped amulet believed to protect against the evil eye, especially in Turkish culture. Depicted as a rich blue, circular bead with a black dot in the center ringed with white and light blue, resembling an eye. Commonly used to represent eyes, various senses of looking, various senses of charms, envy and jealousy, and Turkey and Turkish culture. Also used for its blue color more generally. WhatsApp, Facebook, and Huawei's designs include a small hole, as for threading the amulet on a string or chain. Note: this emoji is not supported in Twitter / X names, to minimize confusion with a verified checkmark. Learn more here.

The symbol for infinity enclosed within a circle or square. Originally encoded as a symbol to represent acid-free paper, this permanent paper sign was later given emoji presentation to form an infinity emoji. May also be used by members of the autism rights movement to represent neurodiversity. Note: this emoji is not supported in Twitter / X names, to minimize confusion with a verified checkmark. Learn more here.
A skull and crossbones displayed on a black flag, used on pirate ships, also known as a Jolly Roger.

A yellow face with eyes closed and mouth wide open covered by a hand. Captured mid-yawn, this may represent having insufficient sleep, or to imply boredom with a person or topic. Not to be confused with 😪 Sleepy Face or 😴 Sleeping Face, which often convey actually being asleep, or 😫 Tired Face which is tired as in "fed up".

A brown heart emoji. As with the other color-based hearts, this emoji is often also used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color. For example, this emoji has been found to often be used to discuss topics related to racial identity. As of February 2021, this emoji was the least used of the nine colored hearts that existed at that time (the others being ❤️, 🧡, 💛, 💚, 💙, 💜,🖤, and 🤍).

A white heart emoji, used for love and affection. Also commonly used to discuss someone passing away or reference something heavenly or angelic. As with the other color-based hearts, this emoji can also often used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color. For this emoji, this often happens with wedding dresses. An alternative character known as White Heart Suit is also available, but not intended to have an emoji appearance.
A hand with thumb and index finger in close proximity. Used to suggest that something is small, or to gesture a small amount.
A mechanical or prosthetic arm.
A mechanical or prosthetic leg.
An ear shown with a hearing aid, worn by a person with hearing loss. The style shown in Behind The Ear (BTE), but this can represent any form of hearing aid.

A person gesturing with their index finger between ear and mouth, used as a deaf sign in American Sign Language (ASL) and a number of other global sign languages. May also be combined with the 🤫 Shushing Face emoji to reference "mewing". See also 🦻 Ear With Hearing Aid.

A man gesturing with their index finger between ear and mouth, used as a deaf sign in American Sign Language (ASL) and a number of other global sign languages. Incorrectly displays with a female design within Windows 11 23H2.

A woman gesturing with their index finger between ear and mouth, used as a deaf sign in American Sign Language (ASL) and a number of other global sign languages. Incorrectly displays with a male design within Windows 11 23H2.
A person standing upright. Commonly used to convey awkwardness, particularly on TikTok. Similar in appearance to 🚶 Person Walking, but shown facing forward and without any motion implied.
A man standing upright. Commonly used to convey awkwardness, particularly on TikTok. Similar in appearance to 🚶‍♂️ Man Walking, but shown facing forward and without any motion implied.
A person standing upright. Commonly used to convey awkwardness, particularly on TikTok. Similar in appearance to 🚶‍♀️ Woman Walking, but shown facing forward and without any motion implied.

A person kneeling down on one or both knees. The intended meaning can vary based on the pose and context.

This emoji may represent someone in prayer, stretching, or resting on the floor. It can also convey broader themes such as submission, humility, or adopting a respectful posture.

In social or political contexts, it may symbolize protest or solidarity.
A man kneeling down on one or both knees. May be used to represent someone in prayer, or a person resting on the floor.
A woman kneeling down on one or both knees. May be used to represent someone in prayer, or a person resting on the floor.
A man using a white cane as a mobility aid, presumably due to them being blind or visually impaired.
A woman using a white cane as a mobility aid, presumably due to them being blind or visually impaired.
A man using a motorized wheelchair as a mobility aid.
A woman using a motorized wheelchair as a mobility aid.
A man using a manual wheelchair as a mobility aid.
A woman using a manual wheelchair as a mobility aid.

Two people holding hands, most likely due to being in a relationship.

No gender is specified for these two people, meaning they are likely to be shown with a gender inclusive design.

An orangutan, the orange-haired ape with long arms. Depicted facing forward, with a long broad face and sitting with its legs bent. Occasionally shown scratching its head. Color varies across platforms, ranging from orange to light brown. This emoji is considered racist in some contexts, particularly when used to disparage, insult, and abuse people with dark skin, especially Black people.

A guide (or Seeing Eye) dog, trained to help lead a person who is blind or visually impaired. Generally depicted as a yellowish-brown Labrador Retriever on all fours facing left, equipped with a harness and handle. Many platforms additionally include a collar. Not to be confused with 🐕‍🦺 Service Dog, though their popular applications may overlap. Twitter implements the same dog as its 🐕 Dog. Samsung and Twitter’s guide dogs have green harnesses.

A service animal displayed with a safety vest and lead. Differs from the guide dog as this animal is intended for detection of seizures or other “hidden disabilities”, according to the proposal from Apple.

A sloth, the slow-moving, tree-dwelling mammal. Depicted as a light-brown sloth with a wide, whitish, masked face hanging from a tree branch, facing left or right. Generally shown as a three-toed sloth.

An otter, the playful water mammal in the weasel family. Depicted as a light-brown otter on its back, with its forepaws held together and whiskered face to the left, generally with its long tail curled up. May be used to refer to certain members of the LGBTQ community, a la the slang term "otter". Apple’s otter is in water, holding a stone, as is Microsoft’s.

A skunk, a bushy-tailed mammal that sprays a foul odor when threatened. Depicted in full profile on all fours facing left, with black hair and its distinctive white stripe running from its head down to a curled-up tail.

Google’s original skunk design bore a humorously haughty air.
