A flamingo, a waterbird with pink feathers and long neck and legs. Depicted as a flamingo in full profile facing left, standing on one leg, usually with a long, black beak.

May be used to represent summer fun or as a pink accent color.
Half of an opened oyster shell with gray, pink, or orange flesh inside. Many platforms also include a pearl in the shell.
A single white or light brown bulb of garlic. Can be used to talk about cooking, eating, or vampire protection.
A round yellow onion. Can be used to talk about cooking, eating, or crying. Sometimes used in metaphors about layers. Might also be used in computing contexts in reference to onion routing.
A round or square Belgian waffle, baked to a golden brown. Most platforms depict this emoji topped with a pad of butter, and some include gooey syrup running down the sides.

Brown spheres depicting falafel, a food popular in Middle Eastern and North African cuisine, typically made of mashed chickpeas or fava beans. Most platforms include three or more falafel with one piece split open to reveal a green center. Can be used to talk about falafel and possibly other round brown food items like meatballs. On several platforms 🥙 Stuffed Flatbread appears to be filled with falafel, so for some users, these two emoji might be interchangeable.
A pale yellow stick of butter. Can be used to talk about cooking or eating. Might also be used in idioms or to reference something that is smooth.

Originally proposed as Juice, this emoji can be used to talk about juice or other liquids that come in boxes with straws. It can also be used metaphorically to talk about power, energy, respect, or an elusive quality that makes someone special. While intended to be used to represent a broad selection of juices and other liquids, most vendors' designs feature a 🍎 Red Apple symbol. 🍇 Grapes, 🍊Tangerine, 🍑 Peach, 🍒 Cherries, 🍐 Pear, and a 🌞 Sun with Face across other more distinct designs.

Mate is a caffeinated beverage popular in many South American countries. Green in color (from a key ingredient: the dried leaves of yerba mate) and consumed via a metal straw. This drink is commonly referred to as yerba mate in English, and sometimes spelled maté (to distinguish from a mate, as in friend).
A blue cube of ice. Can be used to talk about ice or cold temperatures in general. This emoji can also be used metaphorically to talk about something that is cool or chill.
A Hindu temple or mandir; a place of worship for followers of Hinduism. Depicted on most platforms as a red, orange, or golden building with a tall spire.

A manual wheelchair. Most platforms show a red and black or blue and black wheelchair. Distinct from ♿ Wheelchair Symbol, which is used as signage to indicate accessible facilities. See also 👩‍🦽Woman in Manual Wheelchair or 👨‍🦽Man in Manual Wheelchair. 🦼 Motorized Wheelchair was approved at the same time as this emoji.

A motorized wheelchair. Most platforms show a red and black or blue and black wheelchair. Distinct from ♿ Wheelchair Symbol which is used as signage to indicate accessible facilities. See also 👩‍🦼Woman in Motorized Wheelchair or 👨‍🦼Man in Motorized Wheelchair. 🦽 Manual Wheelchair was approved at the same time as this emoji.

An auto rickshaw, often referred to as a tuk tuk. This motorized version of a cycle rickshaw is used for transport in many regions of the world. Generally this emoji has three wheels and open sides without doors.

An open parachute floating through the air with a human steering. Most platforms feature a ram-air design. Colors vary across platforms. Can be used to represent parachuting or skydiving, or to metaphorically represent a quick exit from an awkward or uncomfortable situation.
A ringed planet that appears with various number of rings, tilt angles, and colors across platforms. This vaguely Saturn-like orb was proposed as a stand-alone planet emoji to represent all planets.

A diving mask with a snorkel, used for scuba diving or other underwater activities. Colors vary across platforms. 🥽 Goggles is similar in design, but used primarily to represent safety goggles rather than swimming goggles.
A round yo-yo with its string coming out. It appears in various colors and designs across platforms, occasionally with a ⭐ Star on its side. WhatsApp's yo-yo design displays the company's logo.

A kite. Usually diamond-shaped with a tail, this emoji appears in various colors across platforms. This emoji typically sees a notable uptick in usage around the International Kite Festival (Uttarayan), celebrated from January 14 to January 15 mainly the Indian state of Gujarat. Unlike other vendors, Huawei's design is shaped like a bird of prey.

An orange safety vest with reflective lines across the chest and over the shoulders. Used in the ZWJ sequence 🐕‍🦺 Service Dog, which was approved at the same time. A safety vest can also be seen in the designs of 👷 Construction Worker on multiple platforms.

A brightly colored sari draped in different ways across platforms. Sometimes used to mean a dress in general.

This emoji is sometimes used playfully in English to stand in for the word 'sorry.'
A sporty one-piece swimsuit shown in a variety of colors and patterns across different platforms. Related emojis include 👙 Bikini, 🩳 Shorts, and 🩲 Briefs.

Underwear or swim briefs. The swimming variety are often called 'Speedos' after the brand. This emoji is shown in different colors and styles across platforms. Some platforms depict this emoji as tighty whities with a visible fly, while others use a less specific design. Related emojis include 👙 Bikini, 🩳 Shorts, and 🩱 One-Piece Swimsuit.

Shorts or swimming trunks. This emoji is shown in different colors and styles across platforms. Most platforms depict this emoji in a casual sporty style. Related emojis include 👙 Bikini, 🩲 Briefs, and 🩱 One-Piece Swimsuit.

Shoes worn by ballet dancers for pointe work. Most platforms show a pair of pink shoes resting on their pointes. Sometimes used to represent dancing in general, rather than ballet specifically. Sometimes also used to represent the color pink.
A banjo with a round body and a long neck. Used to talk about banjos or music in general.
A lamp made of brass or clay, displayed with a lit wick leading into oil or ghee. Commonly used in Hindu, Sikh, Jain and Zoroastrian religious festivals such as Diwali.
An axe with a wooden handle and a metal blade. On many platforms the blade is red, like a fire axe.

A white cane, used by some people who are blind or visually impaired. The cane has a black or gray handle with a wrist loop, a white middle section, and a red end with a white cap. This cane differs from a support cane and is sometimes called a probing cane. 👩‍🦯 Woman With Probing Cane and 👨‍🦯 Man With Probing Cane are ZWJ sequences that use White Cane.
A red drop of blood. May be used to talk about bleeding, injury, blood donation, or menstruation.
An adhesive bandage used for first aid. Sometimes called a Band-Aid or band aid after the trademarked product. Sometimes called a plaster.
A stethoscope with a round resonator and two earpieces. Shown in black, blue, green, or red, depending on the platform.

A simple wooden chair. Distinct from 💺 Seat, which is generally depicted as a fixed plane, train, or bus seat, as opposed to a chair which can be moved. May have sexual connotations (e.g., sit on my face). In 2021 this emoji was also used on TikTok to signify laughter or approval or to create confusion for people not in the know. Learn more here.
A safety razor, depicted in various colors across platforms. Previously shown as a straight razor by Microsoft, WhatsApp, and JoyPixels.

A circle shown in the color of orange. As with other color-based shape emojis (most notably the hearts), this emoji may be used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color.

A circle shown in the color of yellow. As with other color-based shape emojis (most notably the hearts), this emoji may be used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color.

A circle shown in the color of green. As with other color-based shape emojis (most notably the hearts), this emoji may be used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color. In February 2025, this emoji became associated with the Green Party in Canada. The party changed its logo to a similar-looking green circle icon and referenced the emoji during its announcement.

A circle shown in the color of purple. May be used to represent anything purple. During 2024 this emoji began to be used by French users of social media platforms to reference a term for a serious form of assault. This was due to its phonetic similarity to the color purple within the French language. Additionally, as with other color-based shape emojis (most notably the hearts), this emoji may also used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color.

A circle shown in the color of brown. As with other color-based shape emojis (most notably the hearts), this emoji may be used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color.
A square shown in the color red. May be used to represent anything red, including a red penalty card in football (soccer).
A square shown in the color of orange. May be used to represent anything orange.

A square shown in the color yellow. When players of the word game Wordle share their results on social platforms the results are represented through a series of green, yellow, and black or white square emojis. This emoji indicates that the player guessed a correct letter but in the wrong place within the word. This emoji is also often used to represent a yellow penalty card in football (soccer). Additionally, as with other color-based shape emojis (most notably the hearts), this emoji may be used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color.

A square shown in the color of green. As with other color-based shape emojis (most notably the hearts), this emoji may be used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color. When players of the word game Wordle share their results on social platforms the results are represented through a series of green, yellow, and black or white square emojis. This emoji indicates that the player guessed a correct letter in its right place. Additionally, in May 2021, this emoji was occasionally shown in X/Twitter names in support of Taproot, a Bitcoin fork (potential feature change) that would allow additional privacy measures for transactions.
A square shown in the color of blue. May be used to represent anything blue.
A square shown in the color of purple. May be used to represent anything purple.
A square shown in the color of brown. May be used to represent anything brown.

A person with red hair. This emoji maintains red hair no matter which skin tone is chosen. This emoji may be used to talk about redheads in a gender-inclusive way. Variants include 👩‍🦰 Woman with Red Hair and 👨‍🦰 Man with Red Hair.
A person with curly hair. This emoji may be used to talk about people with curly hair in a gender-inclusive way. Variants include 👩‍🦱 Woman with Curly Hair and 👨‍🦱 Man with Curly Hair.

A person with white hair. This emoji maintains white hair no matter which skin tone is chosen. This emoji may be used to talk about people with white hair in a gender-inclusive way. Variants include 👩‍🦳 Woman with White Hair and 👨‍🦳 Man with White Hair. See also 🧓 Older Person, which is similar, though is shown with wrinkles and gray hair on most platforms.

A person with a bald head. Can be used to represent a bald person or a person with a shaved head. May also be used to represent a person experiencing hair loss from chemotherapy, alopecia, or other medical treatments or conditions. This emoji may be used to talk about bald people in a gender-inclusive way. Variants include 👩‍🦲 Bald Woman and 👨‍🦲 Bald Man.
A person working in the field of health care. This may be used to represent a doctor, nurse, or pharmacist.
A person who is engaged in education. Generally depicted wearing a black graduation gown and cap, and occasionally holding a degree certificate or diploma.
A person standing in front of a chalkboard (aka blackboard) with the intention of teaching a class. Often shown holding a 📕 Closed Book or a pointer.
A person who presides over court proceedings, wearing the traditional black gown and wielding a gavel.
A person engaged in agriculture, raising living organisms for food or raw materials. Generally depicted as wearing a wide-brimmed hat and holding a crop (such as carrots or corn) or a pitchfork.

A person responsible for food preparation wearing a white buttoned chef jacket and toque hat. Usually shown with either a wooden spoon or a skillet frying an egg, though WhatsApp's design is holding a spatula.
A person engaged in the construction, maintenance, or repair of machinery. Depicted wearing overalls and holding a wrench. Frequently also shown wearing a billed cap.
A person working in a factory setting, depicted as wearing overalls and protective headgear while holding an active welding gun.
A person wearing business attire. This may include items such as a shirt, tie, jacket, or headset.

A person who is studying or has expert knowledge of one or more of the natural or physical sciences. Generally depicted wearing safety goggles and a white lab coat while holding a test tube or beaker filled with colorful liquid.
A person behind a computer screen, working in the field of technology. Usually shown working on a laptop, though Google's design appears to be using a desktop computer instead.
A singer or rock star generally displayed with a microphone, and sometimes musical notes. iOS and Android display this emoji as a Bowie-esque figure while WhatsApp appears heavily inspired by Prince.
A person engaged in the visual art of painting, shown holding a palette and paintbrush.
A person tasked with flying an aircraft, such as an ✈️ Airplane or a 🚁 Helicopter, shown wearing a traditional airline pilot uniform.
An astronaut or cosmonaut shown wearing a space suit and helmet.
A person professionally tasked with controlling and extinguishing fires.
A person using a white cane as a mobility aid, presumably due to them being blind or visually impaired.
A person using a motorized wheelchair as a mobility aid.
A person using a manual wheelchair as a mobility aid.

A yellow face with open eyes, a thin closed-mouth smile, and a single tear falling from one of its eyes. Can be used to express a wide range of emotions and expressions including gratitude, tender happiness, an attempt to look happy when actually sad, or smiling through pain. Can also be a response to something that is bittersweet. This emoji and 🙂 Slightly Smiling Face have a similar smile, and 😢 Crying Face and 😿 Crying Cat have a similar lone tear. Not to be confused with 😂 Face with Tears of Joy, which has a wide toothy grin and tears coming from both eyes.

A yellow face with big glasses, a large nose, thick eyebrows, and a mustache. Used to represent someone in disguise. The features of this particular disguised face are taken from the “Groucho Mask” or “Groucho Glasses,” designed in the likeness of the caricature played by Julius Henry Marx in the Marx Brothers' films. These comedic films were popular in the 1930s and ‘40s, and the mask has been a mainstay of joke shops since as early as the 1940s. Other emoji faces in disguise include 🦸 Superhero and 🦹 Supervillain.

An emoji showing the fingers held together in a vertical orientation, often referred to as the Italian hand gesture ma che vuoi, sometimes called the "finger purse." In Italy this gesture tends to be used in disagreement, frustration, or disbelief and can mean “What do you want?” or “What are you saying?” Outside Italy anyone performing a caricature of an Italian person, regardless of context or tone, might use this gesture. Pinched Fingers has a variety of other culturally specific uses. In Israeli culture it can mean “hold on,” “relax,” or “be patient.” The K-Pop star Yuri uses it as a signature gesture to represent a dumpling and a general warm sentiment. It can also be used to represent the act of fisting. Not to be confused with 🤏 Pinching Hand, which has overlapping senses. Both are used to represent precision when someone is making a sharp point with accompanying speech.
A red anatomical heart, shown with blue or purple veins on some platforms. Sometimes used interchangeably with ❤️ Red Heart.

Pink anatomical lungs and trachea, shown with bronchial tubes on some platforms. Used in medical contexts to talk about lung health. Sometimes used in reference to taking deep breaths, hyperventilating, or breathing in general. Also used in the context of smoking or vaping.

A person dressed as a ninja with a black hood, a mask covering the lower half of their face, and the hilt of a knife or sword emerging from behind their shoulder. This emoji is considered racist in some contexts, particularly when used to disparage, insult, and abuse people with dark skin, especially Black people. The now-discontinued Microsoft ZWJ sequence 🐱‍👤 Ninja Cat did not include the ninja emoji at all as it was developed several years before ninja was approved. It combined 🐱 Cat Face and 👤 Bust in Silhouette and was only available from Microsoft prior to the debut of the Fluent emoji set in November 2021.
A man dressed for a formal occasion, wearing a tuxedo.
A woman dressed for a formal occasion, wearing a tuxedo.
A man wearing a traditional Western wedding dress with a veil over their head.
A woman wearing a traditional western wedding dress with a veil over their head.

A woman feeding a baby with a bottle, sometimes looking down to the infant and smiling. This emoji supports skin tone modifiers, which apply to the adult. The head of the baby is recommended to be hidden to avoid a situation where the skin tone of the baby would only correlate to the skin tone of the adult. Variants include 🧑‍🍼 Person Feeding Baby and 👨‍🍼 Man Feeding Baby. See also 🤱 Breast-Feeding.

A man feeding a baby with a bottle, sometimes looking down to the infant and smiling. This emoji supports skin tone modifiers, which apply to the adult. The head of the baby is recommended to be hidden to avoid a situation where the skin tone of the baby would only correlate to the skin tone of the adult. Variants include 🧑‍🍼 Person Feeding Baby and 👩‍🍼 Woman Feeding Baby. See also 🤱 Breast-Feeding.

A person feeding a baby with a bottle, sometimes looking down to the infant and smiling. This emoji supports skin tone modifiers, which apply to the adult. The head of the baby is recommended to be hidden to avoid a situation where the skin tone of the baby would only correlate to the skin tone of the adult. Variants include 👩‍🍼 Woman Feeding Baby and 👨‍🍼 Man Feeding Baby. See also 🤱 Breast-Feeding.

A person, generally depicted as being older with gray hair, wearing a red Christmas (aka "Santa") hat. Does not represent any specific character in folklore. Mx Claus provides a gender inclusive alternative to 🎅 Santa Claus or 🤶 Mrs. Claus. Apple depicts Mx Claus as wearing glasses, while other vendors do not. Mx is an honorific that does not indicate gender.

Two people hugging, shown as faceless blue forms on most platforms. Details of each person are not distinct and thus no options are available to customize the gender or skin tone of either individual. Not to be confused with 🤗 Hugging Face, which is less clearly a representation of hugging and sometimes used as jazz hands or to express excitement.
A black cat shown in full profile, often with its tail curling upward.

A brown bison shown in full profile with horns, a beard, and woolly mane. Also called a buffalo in North America. This emoji is frequently associated with the Buffalo Bills, an American football team.
A brown wooly mammoth with large curved tusks. Can also be used to represent a mastodon.

A brown beaver with buckteeth and a wide paddle-like tail. Can be used in the context of actual beavers, or metaphorically to evoke qualities of beavers like working hard, as in the expression beavering away. Commonly associated with Canada, as beavers are a national emblem of the country. May also be used in reference to the vagina, which is an informal sense of the word beaver.
A friendly, cartoon-styled face of polar bear, looking straight ahead. Depicted as the face of a white bear with round ears. WhatsApp previously showed the full body of the bear.

A brown or gray dodo shown in full profile. Generally depicted with a curved yellow beak, small wings, a fluffy white tail, yellow or orange feet, and black talons.

May be used to represent dodos or the concept of being extinct.

A single feather slanted to one side. On most platforms it's light brown with a dark brown barred or striped pattern. Can be used to talk about feathers or birds, or to represent something that is lightweight, fluffy, or soft.

A gray seal with dark eyes and a dark nose. Most platforms feature a design with whiskers. Can be used to talk about seals, marine life, or cute animals in general. May also be used in phrases with 'sealed' as in sealed with a kiss, my lips are sealed, seal of approval, or signed, sealed, and delivered.

A green or brown beetle shown with antennae and six legs. Can be used to talk about beetles, bugs, or insects in general. Not to be confused with 🐞 Lady Beetle, 🪳 Cockroach, 🐛 Bug, 🐜 Ant or other emoji representations of insects.

A brown cockroach shown with antennae, six legs, and two sensory pads at its rear called cerci.

Can be used to talk about cockroaches or insects in general. May also be used metaphorically as an insult to call a person a pest, an annoyance, or to suggest they are subhuman.

A fly with a dark or iridescent green body, six legs, and two translucent wings. On most platforms, its eyes are red.

Can be used to talk about the insect or flight in general. May also be used metaphorically as an adjective meaning "cool."

A pink or brown worm. Most platforms have more realistic designs, though Google and Samsung feature cartoony worms who are smiling sweetly.

Can be used to talk about worms or disease spread by worms. Can also be used to refer to a deceitful person. May be used to in reference to the dance move 'the worm.'

A leafy green plant in pot. Plant type varies by platform.

Occasionally used as slang for marijuana.
A few ripe blueberries clustered together. Most platforms show three blueberries, and some show small green leaves coming out from behind the blueberries.

One, two, or three green olives, either pitted or sprouting from a branch. Some platforms show a solitary pitted green olive stuffed with a piece of a pimento pepper.

Can be used to talk about olives or the color green.
A perfectly ripe red or green bell pepper. Can be used to talk about bell peppers or food in general.

A round piece of flatbread with grill marks. Used to represent any type of flatbread, soft or crunchy. Can be used to talk about corn-based flatbreads popular in Central and South America like arepa, gordita, or pupusa. Can also be used in reference to other flatbreads including naan, lavash, matzah, and pita. Not to be confused with 🥙 Stuffed Flatbread.
A single tamale wrapped in a corn husk.
A red fondue pot. Most platforms show cheese fondue with fondue forks sticking out of the pot.

A classic teapot with a wide bulbous body, a spout, a handle, and a lid. Can be used to talk about tea, tea time, or warm beverages in general. May also be used to talk about gossip as in the expression spill the tea.
Bubble tea is a tea-based drink invented in Taiwan which typically contain tea, flavored milk, and sugar. Commonly served with tapioca pearls, also known as boba, in a plastic cup with a wide straw.

A large rock the size of a small rock. May be considered a boulder, a rock, a stone, a pebble, or a piece of dirt. The scale and meaning are context-dependent. The color is gray or brownish gray across vendor's designs. May be used as a disparaging remark about a person's perceived lack of intelligence.

One or two stumps of wood, cut so the rings are showing. Can be used to talk about wood or building materials. Also used in idioms with wood like knock on wood or out of the woods. Used to caption dic pics, often alongside the expression morning wood. Sometimes used in the context of games like Catan or Minecraft, where wood is a resource.
A round hut with a thatched roof. Used to talk about huts, cottages, yurts, or homes in general.
A red or turquoise pickup truck. Used to talk about trucks or modes of transportation in general.
A single vibrantly colored roller skate. Colors and styles vary across platform.

A wand with sparkles (✨magic✨) coming out of its end. Most platforms show a classic magician-style magic wand that's black with white tips. WhatsApp shows a golden magic wand tipped with a star, similar to the wand that Glenda the Good Witch uses in the 1939 film The Wizard of Oz.

A colorful decorated container that comes in many shapes, a piñata is filled with candy or toys. Hit to break open for celebrations such as Cinco de Mayo, this is generally associated with Mexico. Displayed as a donkey on some platforms, and as a three-dimensional star with 6–9 points on others.

Nesting dolls, also called matryoshka dolls or Russian dolls, decorated with bright colors including red, yellow, blue, and green.

All platforms depict the nesting dolls as open, revealing smaller dolls within the bases of larger dolls. Dolls are all decorated with women wearing headscarfs. Some platforms show a flower motif on the women's dresses or aprons.

A threaded silver needle. Color of thread varies from platform to platform.

Can be used to talk about crafts including embroidery, quilting, or sewing in general. Can also be used in medical contexts to talk about stitches.

Used metaphorically at the beginning of a thread, or series of connected posts by one person, on social media.

Brightly colored rope forming a knot. Knot type varies across platform, with most designs showing a square knot, a figure eight knot, or a carrick bend. Samsung's design appears to be a carrick bend, but upon closer inspection, it is not correctly tied and would fall apart with a gentle tug. Used to talk about rope or knots in general. Sometimes used in the context of marriage alongside the idiom tying the knot. Also used in the kink community to talk about bondage. May be used as a stand-in for the word 'not' in emoji rebus puzzles.
A single flip flop or thong sandal. Often worn to the beach and/or in warm weather. Can be used to talk about sandals, the beach, or warm weather in general.
A round military helmet with a chinstrap. All platforms depict a green helmet, with some designs featuring a green camouflage pattern.

A red accordion with a keyboard on one side, buttons on the other side, and bellows in the middle. Used to talk about accordion music or music in general. Also may be used in reference to things that expand and contract, or are folded like the bellows of an accordion.

A long drum with a tall body and a cylindrical or hourglass shell. Can be used to represent various drums found around the world from Africa to the Caribbean to Latin America to Asia. Types of long drum include (but are not limited to) djembe, talking drum, conga, bongo, tumbadora, atabaque, and dhol.

Can also be used to talk about drums, music, or beats in general.

A coin shown in silver or gold. Design varies by platform, with Google and Twitter showing a 🏛️ Classical Building and Samsung showing the number one, similar to their 🥇 1st Place Medal design. Apple’s coin has the text "The Crazy Ones," a reference to its 1997–2002 Crazy Ones/Think Different ad campaign and commonly used as placeholder text in Apple icons and emoji designs.

A wooden boomerang with bright colors on its tips. Google and Twitter's designs show motion lines to illustrate the path of a boomerang.

Used literally to represent a boomerang. Also used to represent Aboriginal people or Australia in general. May be used to represent something that comes back or returns.
A long silver saw with a wooden handle. Used to represent construction, carpentry, renovation, or tools in general.

A silver Phillips-head or slotted-head screwdriver with a colorful handle. Most platforms show a red handle, though Apple's design has a green handle. Used to represent construction, building, carpentry, renovation, or tools in general. Sometimes used in phrases with 'screw' in them like screw you or have a screw loose. Can also be used in sexual contexts due to the informal meaning of 'screw': "to have sex."

A gold or silver hook. Can be used to represent literal hooks like the kinds you use to crochet or catch fish. Also use metaphorically to talk about boxing or punching, music (the catchy part of a song), or in phrases like hook me up, hook up, getting hooked (on something), or hook, line, and sinker.

A wooden ladder with four or five rungs.

Used to represent ladders or the action of climbing. Also used metaphorically to represent systems through which you can climb, for example the corporate ladder or social ladder.

A symbol showing two or three people standing in a square with up and down arrows above them. Most platforms feature a simple blue and white design.

Mostly used to talk about elevators. Also used metaphorically to talk about moving or leveling up or down.

A mirror with an ornate gold or silver frame. The shape and style of the mirror varies from platform to platform.

Used to talk about mirrors, reflection, or self-reflection.

A square or rectangular window with glass panes. Most platforms show a wooden frame with two or four panels.

Used to talk about actual windows or metaphorical windows, which often represent opportunities, perspectives, or unique points of view.

A toilet plunger with a wooden handle and red flange and cup.

Used to talk about toilets and clogged pipes. Also used metaphorically to talk about a mess or something that's disgusting.

A trap used to catch a mouse, rat, or other unwanted rodent. Metaphorically used in emoji form to suggest any kind of trap or entrapment. The style of trap shown on major platforms has a box held high with a single stick. A wedge of cheese is used to lure a mouse into the box, knocking the stick away and trapping — but not killing — the mouse. This is distinct from other traps which kill or injure upon capture.

A blue or green bucket or pail. Used to talk about real or metaphorical buckets.

May be used to talk about bucket lists, kicking the bucket, making baskets in basketball, an abundance of something (like rain or money), and many other contexts.

A brightly colored plastic toothbrush with white bristles.

Used to talk about oral hygiene, daily routines, or something that is fresh and clean.

A headstone or tombstone, used to mark graves. Appearance varies from platform to platform, with different shapes and inscriptions. Used to talk about death — literally, metaphorically, and metaphysically. Often paired with other death-related emoji like ⚰️ Coffin and ☠️ Skull and Crossbones.

A sign on a post, commonly used to promote ideas, causes, or make announcements. Often used used in the context of politics to represent a lawn sign or a poster brought to a protest. Also seen in commercial advertising.

Shown with indiscernible writing or not writing at all, this emoji is flexible in its use. WhatsApp shows a peace sign, which tilts the meaning away from commercial use.

A symbol commonly used to represent those in the transgender community. Used within the draft emoji sequence for the Transgender Flag emoji, and also given emoji presentation on Samsung devices. Shows as a plain text character on other platforms.
A flag with horizontal pale blue and pale pink stripes with a single white stripe in the middle, used as a Transgender or Transgender Pride flag and commonly seen at Pride events.

A face that appears surrounded by clouds or a haze of smoke. Ambiguous in appearance, this may represent a foggy state of mind, confusion, or even a sense of calm bliss. May also be used to indicate the presence of smoke.
A face showing a visible breath of air being dispelled. Used to represent relief, exhaustion, or as a sigh of disappointment or displeasure. May also be used to indicate the exhaling of smoke.

A face with spiral-shaped eyes, commonly used to indicate dizziness, but may also represent hypnosis or other forms of disorientation. Created in 2020 disambiguate from the 😵 Face with Crossed-Out Eyes emoji which previously displayed spiral eyes on some platforms, but X eyes on others. This emoji will consistently show spiral eyes on all platforms. Unlike other vendors, Huawei's design features a 💫 Dizzy symbol atop this emoji's head.
A heart shown on fire, for extreme or passionate forms of love or lust. Most representative of desire or lust, this emoji may also indicate a sense of burning a past love and moving on.

A heart shown with a bandage across one side; the opposite of a broken heart. May be used to indicate the process of healing, recovery, or to express sympathy for someone going through a difficult time.
A man shown with long hair and a beard. Note that as of late 2021, Samsung's design displays this emoji with a more gender-neutral design than that used for their 🧔 Person with Beard emoji.
A woman shown with long hair and a beard.

A yellow smiley face melting into a puddle. 

The eyes and mouth slip down the face, yet still maintain a distorted smile. This quality lends this emoji to sarcasm.

Can be used literally to talk about extreme heat. Can also be used metaphorically to talk about embarrassment, shame, a slowly sinking sense of dread, or feeling overwhelmed in some way.

A yellow face with open (non-smiling) eyes and a hand over the mouth, used to convey shock or surprise. A disambiguation of 🤭 Face with Hand Over Mouth which appears to have smiling eyes on some platforms, and open/non-smiling eyes on others, creating confusion. Appearance is similar to 🥱 Yawning Face, though no mouth is visible.

A yellow face with its hands over its eyes and raised eyebrows. One wide eye is peeking through the fingers.

Can be used to express the duality of wanting to look away from something because it's frightening, disgusting, or embarrassing, but not being able to.

A yellow face with its right hand saluting. Used as a sign of respect. The expression of the face of this emoji can vary across platforms, with some designs featuring a neutral face while others are shown smiling to various degrees. Apple and Huewai's designs notably only display half a face, likely to make the saluting hand more prominent when this emoji is viewed in smaller sizes. Can be considered an emoji version of the o7 emoticon, where the "o" represents a head and the "7" depicts a raised arm in a salute. Variants of o7 remain popular within gaming communities and on platforms such as Twitch.

A muted yellow neutral face with a dotted or dashed outline. An established comic book trope, dotted lines around a character can represent someone that is invisible or hidden. It can also represent smallness, submissiveness, isolation, and depression. This emoji has the same expression as 😐 Neutral Face.
A yellow face with a closed slanted mouth. Can be used to express skepticism, confusion, or frustration.

A yellow face with tears welling up at the bottom of its two large eyes. May be used to express a range of emotions including sadness, anger, embarrassment, admiration, and gratitude. 🥲 Smiling Face with Tear and 🥺 Pleading Face can be used in some similar contexts.

An open right hand facing right, so as to show the back of the hand with the thumb on the top and the pinky on the bottom. This emoji was developed along with 🫲 Leftwards Hand to allow for the creation of ZWJ Sequences that depict 🤝 Handshake with two different skin tone modifiers applied, one to each hand.

An open right hand facing left, so as to show the palm of the hand with the thumb on the top and the pinky on the bottom. This emoji was developed along with 🫱 Rightwards Hand to allow for the creation of ZWJ Sequences that depict 🤝 Handshake with two different skin tone modifiers applied, one to each hand.

A hand in profile with the palm facing down. Can be used to represent the action of dropping or reaching for something. May also be used in a variety of culture-specific contexts, including dismissal, negotiation, or as a beckoning gesture. The design is the inverse of 🫴 Palm Up Hand.

A hand in profile with the palm facing up. Can be used to represent the action of lifting, offering, demanding, or beckoning. May also be used to express a question or lack of knowledge. The design is the inverse of 🫴 Palm Down Hand. The hand position is similar to the one in 💁 Person Tipping Hand.

A hand with the index finger and thumb crossed and the rest of the fingers making a fist. Can be used in various contexts to represent the fingers snapping, love, or money. In this emoji, the index finger and the thumb form a small heart shape. This gesture, used to express love or affection, is known as a finger heart and was popularized in the 2010s by South Korean celebrities, including actors, K-pop stars, and comedians. In the context of money, this gesture may be used to indicate a luxury or an expensive item, a lack of money, or a request to be paid. It may also be used to represent playing a tiny violin.

A hand with the index finger pointing straight forward at the person viewing the emoji. Used to represent the word and concept of 'you,' the second-person singular and plural pronoun.

This symbol is seen in art, advertisements, and military recruitment posters as a way to draw the viewer into the image they're looking at.

This hand shape is also used in multiple sign languages from around the world.

Two hands forming a heart shape. Used to express love and support.

This emoji currently showns the heart being made through two hands being curved into a C-shape with their thumbs touching. This is stereotypically referred to as the "Millennial Hand Heart".

Two hands forming a heart shape. Used to express love and support.

This emoji currently showns the heart being made through two hands being curved into a C-shape with their thumbs touching. This is stereotypically referred to as the "Millennial Hand Heart".

Two hands forming a heart shape. Used to express love and support.

This emoji currently showns the heart being made through two hands being curved into a C-shape with their thumbs touching. This is stereotypically referred to as the "Millennial Hand Heart".

Two hands forming a heart shape. Used to express love and support.

This emoji currently showns the heart being made through two hands being curved into a C-shape with their thumbs touching. This is stereotypically referred to as the "Millennial Hand Heart".

Two hands forming a heart shape. Used to express love and support.

This emoji currently showns the heart being made through two hands being curved into a C-shape with their thumbs touching. This is stereotypically referred to as the "Millennial Hand Heart".

Two hands forming a heart shape. Used to express love and support.

This emoji currently showns the heart being made through two hands being curved into a C-shape with their thumbs touching. This is stereotypically referred to as the "Millennial Hand Heart".

A mouth with the top teeth biting down on one side of the lower lip.

Used in romantic contexts to express flirtation or arousal. Can be used to express anticipation or excitement in general. Also may be used to express anxiety, pain, worry, or insecurity.
A person wearing a crown. 👸 Princess and 🤴 Prince were added in 2015 and 2016, respectively. Person With Crown was created to represent royalty without being overly specific about gender.

A pregnant man holding his round stomach. Sometimes used in jest to represent feeling too full after overeating, as in a "food baby." Variants include 🫄 Pregnant Person and 🫃 Pregnant Woman. This emoji was approved to make the emoji keyboard more consistent and gender inclusive.

A pregnant person holding their round stomach. Sometimes used in jest to represent feeling too full after overeating, as in a "food baby." Variants include 🫄 Pregnant Woman and 🫃 Pregnant Man. This emoji was approved to make the emoji keyboard more consistent and gender inclusive.

A green troll, usually shown holding a club.

May be used to refer to the fantasy creature. May also be used to refer to an internet troll or the act of trolling.

Apple’s troll holds a scepter instead of a club. Microsoft, Twitter, and WhatsApp's designs show only the bust of a troll instead of the full-bodied creature.

Coral as found in a reef, of varying shapes and colors. Sometimes used as a symbol of climate change due to coral bleaching. Depending on the emoji keyboard being used, this emoji may appear among either animal or plant emojis. This variation notably resulted in criticism from social media users following the release of iOS 15.4, as corals are animals, not plants.
A pink lotus flower in full bloom. May be used to represent beauty, purity, calmness, or serenity. May also be used along with 🧘 Person in Lotus Position to represent yoga or meditation.

An empty bird's nest. May be used to talk about actual nests or birds. May also be used to talk about home in general or to represent phrases like nest egg or empty nest. 🪺 Nest with Eggs was approved at the same time and may be used along with Empty Nest.

A bird's nest with eggs inside. May be used to talk about actual nests or birds. May also be used to talk about home in general or to represent phrases like nest egg or empty nest. 🪹 Empty Nest was approved at the same time as Nest with Eggs.

Beans, as used in cuisines around the world. May be used to talk about food, flatulence (caused by eating beans), or coffee beans. Also used to discuss money, counting, or a small amount of something. May be used to refer to the head. Additionally may be used with phrases such as spill the beans, full of beans, or cool beans. This emoji is alluded to in the 2025 hit Netflix show Adolescence. Learn more here.

A glass pouring liquid.

May be used to represent the literal act of pouring. May also be used to represent ritual libations or to honor the dead by pouring out a drink in a person's memory.

An empty glass jar. May be used to talk about jars or anything that comes in jars, from pickles to condiments to jellies to sauces. On TikTok, people often pair the jar emoji with prompts like "fill this jar," asking commenters to add certain emojis in response (for example, hearts for "fill this jar with hearts"). This is an engagement tactic to help boost a post’s reach, most commonly appearing on videos promoting charitable causes or fundraisers.

A slide with a ladder, as seen in children's playgrounds. May be used to talk about children, parks, or playtime. May also be used metaphorically to talk about a smooth movement or action like the popular dance the electric slide or sliding into someone's DMs, usually for the purpose of flirting. Additionally may be used in reference to something with a downward descent.
A wheel with a rubber tire. May be used in reference to wheels, tires, or vehicles with wheels. May also be used in expressions with 'wheel' like third wheel or hell on wheels.

A round white and orange or red ring buoy with string laced through its perimeter. Also called a life preserver.

Maybe be used to talk about water, boats, and safety. May also be used metaphorically to talk about someone or something that saves.

A mirror ball, also called a disco ball. A hanging sphere made up of a bunch of tiny mirrors, which reflect spots of light around a room, creating a party atmosphere. Often used by Swifties to reference Taylor Swift's 2020 song mirrorball.

A battery with a minimal amount of power remaining, indicated by the color red. Used to show low power or energy and the need to be plugged in or recharged. May be used to express exhaustion, fatigue or sadness, though often with a sense of irony. Ironic use of this emoji increased in frequency in early 2025, especially on TikTok.
A basic crutch made of metal and rubber.

An X-ray image. Most designs show a human thorax (including the rib cage and shoulder blades). Microsoft shows a skull, while X's design shows a hand. May be used to talk about X-rays or medicine in general.
A few floating bubbles. May be used to represent soap suds, carbonation, or an effervescent personality.

A blue hand with an eye in the center of the palm.

The hamsa is an ancient symbol important to multiple religions including Islam, Judaism, Buddhism, and Christianity. It represents luck, protection, guidance, feminine power, and faith, among other meanings.
An identification card with a portrait and words. May be used to remind people to bring or show an id. May also be used in the context of a fake id.
An equals sign in the style of the already existing set of mathematical symbols ✖️ Multiply, ➕ Plus, ➖ Minus, and ➗ Divide.

A face that appears to be shaking from side to side with its eyes and mouth open wide.

This emoji finds its origins in the comic book and cartoon trope of a shaking face. It can be used to express shaking from external forces like earthquakes, loud noises, or dinosaurs walking nearby. It can also be used to express shaking caused by strong emotions such as shock, fear, confusion, disbelief, anticipation, and excitement. Additionally it can represent dizziness, double takes, or double vision.

A plain pink heart, expected to be frequently used alongside other hearts. Used to represent love, friendship, and feelings of warmth, and the color pink. For many years before its introduction in 2022, the plain pink heart was one of the world's most frequently requested emojis. As with the other color-based hearts, this emoji is often also used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color. This emoji is mentioned in the 2025 hit Netflix show Adolescence. Learn more here. On several platforms, pink hearts are used in the design of other emojis. These emojis include: Sparkling Heart 💖, Two Hearts 💕, Growing Heart 💗, Beating Heart 💓, Revolving Heart 💞, Heart with Arrow 💘, Heart with Ribbon 💝, and Kiss 💏.

A light blue heart, frequently used alongside other hearts. As with the other color-based hearts, this emoji is often also used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color.

A grey heart emoji.

As with the other color-based hearts, this emoji is often also used to express an affinity with or appreciation for various people, places, groups, objects, or ideas associated with the same color.

A profile of an open hand pushing or positioned with the palm toward the left. May be used to show a hand pushing something away or to represent rejection of something in general. May also be used with with 🫸 Rightwards Pushing Hand to show hands high fiving or holding, pressing, or squishing something.

A profile of an open hand pushing or positioned with the palm toward the right. May be used to show a hand pushing something away or to represent rejection of something in general. May also be used with 🫷 Leftwards Pushing Hand to show hands high fiving or holding, pressing, or squishing something.

A moose head with large antlers.

Can be used to talk about the actual animal. Can also be used to represent countries, including Canada and Sweden, where the moose is considered a national symbol. Can also be used alongside the phrase "cool as a moose."

Google’s Moose is facing left, while Twitter displays a full-bodied moose.

A grey donkey or mule, shown in full profile, sometimes with its hind legs kicking into the air. Can be used literally to represent the pack animal. Can also be used metaphorically to call someone a jackass or to say that someone is stubborn as a mule. Because the donkey is a symbol of the Democratic Party of the United States, it may be used in political contexts. Additionally, the term mule can refer to someone who carries illegal drugs across borders, so this emoji may be used to talk about smugglers and the act of smuggling.

A single white wing with feathers. Can be used to talk about flying, both literally and metaphorical. May be used in phrases such as when pigs fly or time flies. May also be used to talk about angels or to say that someone or something is angelic.

A bird with black feathers, shown either standing in full profile or as a bird head. Can be used to represent various black-feathered birds, such as crows, ravens, blackbirds, and more. Black-feathered birds have been associated with magic and the occult across many global cultures, often as an omen of bad tidings. Frequently associated with the Baltimore Ravens, an American football team.

A white goose in full profile. Can be used to talk about the actual animal. Can also be used in the context of idioms including silly goose, wild goose chase, or what's good for the goose is good for the gander. Can also be used to talk about goosebumps or goose pimples. Might be used in reference to the children's game duck duck goose.
A brightly colored jellyfish with a domed bell and dangling tentacles.

A hyacinth with purple blossoms and a green stem. Can be used to talk about the actual flower, flowers in general, or the color purple. Can also be used in reference to springtime. May be used as part of the symbolic table setting for Nowruz, the Persian New Year.

A segment of ginger root with light brown skin and a yellowish core.

Can be used to talk about ginger root or roots in general. Can also be used to talk about spice, flavor, cooking, or baking. May also be also be used to talk redheads.

A green pea pod split to reveal a row of peas inside. Can be used to talk about actual pea pods or peas, pods or vegetables in general, or the color green. May be used along with the phrase two peas in a pod.

A brightly colored folding hand fan. Can be used to talk about fans, both manual and electric. Can also be used to reference various dances involving fans, including the Korean dance of Buchaechum, the Japanese dance of Nihon-buyō, and the Maranao dance of the Singkil. May be used to refer to a person who is a fan (or admirer) of someone or something. May also be used along with the phrases fan the flames or when shit hits the fan.

A hair pick with a handle and several long teeth. Used to style hair, especially thick, curly hair. May be used as a symbol of Black culture or Black pride. 

May also be used to talk about grooming or self-care in general.

May be used metaphorically to refer to the verb comb, meaning "to carefully search."
A set of maracas with a colorful motif painted on them.
A simple yellow flute made of bamboo, plastic, or metal.
The Khanda, the symbol of Sikhism.
The symbol for a wireless or Wi-Fi connection enclosed in a square.

A yellow smiley face with closed eyes and a mouth with a subtle upward curl, shown with motion lines indicating that the smiley is shaking its head back and forth horizontally.

This is intended to depict a shaking head gesture, which is commonly (but not universally) used to indicate disagreement, denial, or rejection.

A yellow smiley face with closed eyes and a mouth with a subtle upward curl, shown with motion lines indicating that the smiley is shaking its head up and down vertically. This is intended to depict a nodding gesture, which is commonly (but not universally) used to indicate agreement, acceptance, or acknowledgment.
A person going for a walk, heading rightwards. Taking a slow-medium pace, this person would be a runner if they picked up their speed.
A woman going for a walk, heading rightwards. Taking a slow-medium pace, this person would be a runner if they picked up their speed.
A man going for a walk, heading rightwards. Taking a slow-medium pace, this person would be a runner if they picked up their speed.
A person kneeling down on one or both knees, facing rightwards. May be used to represent someone in prayer, or a person resting on the floor.
A woman kneeling down on one or both knees, facing rightwards. May be used to represent someone in prayer, or a person resting on the floor.
A man kneeling down on one or both knees, facing rightwards. May be used to represent someone in prayer, or a person resting on the floor.
A rightwards-facing person using a white cane as a mobility aid, presumably due to them being blind or visually impaired.
A rightwards-facing man using a white cane as a mobility aid, presumably due to them being blind or visually impaired.
A rightwards-facing woman using a white cane as a mobility aid, presumably due to them being blind or visually impaired.
A rightwards-facing person using a motorized wheelchair as a mobility aid.
A rightwards-facing man using a motorized wheelchair as a mobility aid.
A rightwards-facing woman using a motorized wheelchair as a mobility aid.
A rightwards-facing person using a manual wheelchair as a mobility aid.
A rightwards-facing man using a manual wheelchair as a mobility aid.
A rightwards-facing woman using a manual wheelchair as a mobility aid.
A person running rightwards, with a large stride and arms outstretched. May be wearing a running shirt.
A woman running rightwards, with a large stride and arms outstretched. May be wearing a running shirt.
A man running rightwards, with a large stride and arms outstretched. May be wearing a running shirt.
A family unit shown with two adults and one child. Usually depicted as a collection of silhouettes on a block color background, as per Unicode's recommendations.
A family unit shown with two adults and two children. Usually depicted as a collection of silhouettes on a block color background, as per Unicode's recommendations.
A family unit shown with one adult and one child. Usually depicted as a collection of silhouettes on a block color background, as per Unicode's recommendations.
A family unit shown with one adult and two children. Usually depicted as a collection of silhouettes on a block color background, as per Unicode's recommendations.
A phoenix, a mythical immortal bird with flame-like feathers found in the folklore of many global cultures. Often used to symbolize renewal or rebirth.
The sour, green-colored citrus fruit of the lime, usually shown as a single sliced wedge.

The edible fungus of the mushroom, depicted as a toadstool with a brown cap and stem. Can be used to represent culinary mushrooms, such as cremini, shiitake, or portobello. Distinct from the 🍄 Mushroom emoji, which features the red cap and white spots that tend to be indicative of various poisonous fungi.

A single length of metal chain that has had one of its links forcefully broken apart. Usually displayed with emphasis marks around the fracture point.

Can be used to discuss freedom and liberty, as well as various types of malfunction.
A smiley face with a strained expression and dark markings under its eyes, likely caused by stress or exhaustion.

A human fingerprint.

Google's designs for this emoji contain a subtle question mark (?).
A bare tree trunk with branches lacking in leaves.
A root vegetable that has been extracted from the earth.

A harp – a triangular stringed musical instrument that is played by having its vertical strings plucked with the fingers.

Closely linked to traditional music in many cultures, the harp holds a particularly strong connection to Ireland, where it serves as the official emblem of the Irish government and the iconic logo of the well-known Irish brewer, Guinness.
A tool used to move loose material such as sand, coal, or snow.
A chaotic splash of an unknown liquid, possibly thick or viscous like paint. Generally colored purple.

The “exceptionally reserved” ISO 3166 code for Sark, which may show as the letters CQ on some platforms. The flag for Sark was the first flag emoji sequence using two-letter ISO codes to be recommended by Unicode since they first formally approved emoji flags through Emoji 1.0 back in 2015.
